				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Introduction to Ethnomusicology</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>MUSC 1900 S01 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 16534]</span></h3>


  	This seminar offers an introduction to theory and method in ethnomusicology, a discipline grounded in ethnographic research and writing on musical practices. We will think, talk, and write about how and why people make music, as well as how and why ethnomusicologists go about their work. Students will undertake independent fieldwork projects, learning first-hand about both the special potential and the practical/ethical challenges of this type of research. Case studies highlight such issues as tradition, appropriation, postcolonial politics, and the ethics of fieldwork. Prerequisites: sophomore standing; MUSC 0550 or instructor permission.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>20</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Kiri+M+Miller">Kiri M Miller</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
					<dt>Meetings</dt>
									<dd>
						<span class="room"> </span>
						<span class="times">10:30 - 11:50 Tue, Thu - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017</span>
						</dd>
							
		
		
		
					<dt>Exam Group Code</dt>
			<dd>13</dd>
		


		</dl>
  </div>

  </div>
</li>
      </ul>

  <h2><a href="/academics/music/node/" title=""></a></h2>

<!-- Layout -->

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Stephen Sondheim and the American Musical</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>MUSC 0021J S01 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 16535]</span></h3>


  	This seminar considers the theater shows of Stephen Sondheim in relation to the history of the American musical. Through close study of selected scenes and shows, we examine how and why Sondheim and his collaborators “reinvented” the genre. Special emphasis will be given to Sondheim's critical skepticism concerning the myths, characters, and ethos of social optimism that have been central to the Broadway tradition. We examine links between the shows and post-WWII historical contexts, and consider the political implications of the circumscribed social universe—predominantly white, urban, and affluent—within which most of his shows take place. FYS
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>20</dd>
		
					<dt>Course Attributes</dt>
						<dd>First Year Seminar</dd>
			
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Dana+A+Gooley">Dana A Gooley</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
					<dt>Meetings</dt>
									<dd>
						<span class="room"> </span>
						<span class="times">13:00 - 14:20 Tue, Thu - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017</span>
						</dd>
							
		
		
		
					<dt>Exam Group Code</dt>
			<dd>10</dd>
		


		</dl>
  </div>

  <h2><a href="/academics/music/node/" title=""></a></h2>


  <div class="content">
          </div>

<!-- Layout -->

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Introduction to Composition</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>MUSC 1100 S01 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 16536]</span></h3>


  	Composition students begin by using technical resources developed in their previous theoretical studies. Analysis and discussion of contemporary music provides examples of alternatives to traditional compositional strategies, which students integrate into later assignments. A study of contemporary notational practices and computer-based manuscripting and sequencing is also included. Prerequisite: MUSC 0560 or permission of the instructor.  Enrollment limited to 20 students.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>20</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Lu+Wang">Lu Wang</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
					<dt>Meetings</dt>
									<dd>
						<span class="room"> </span>
						<span class="times">15:00 - 17:30 Wed - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017</span>
						</dd>
							
		
		
		
					<dt>Exam Group Code</dt>
			<dd>17</dd>
		


		</dl>
  </div>

							</div>

							
													</div><!-- end .second-column -->

          <li class="views-row views-row-1 views-row-odd views-row-first">  
  <div class="views-field-title">
                <span class="field-content"><a href="/academics/music/events/piano-workshop-37">Piano Workshop</a></span>
  </div>
</li>
          <li class="views-row views-row-2 views-row-even views-row-last">  
  <div class="views-field-title">
                <span class="field-content"><a href="/academics/music/events/garlands-steven-stucky-gloria-cheng-recital">Garlands for Steven Stucky: Gloria Cheng in Recital</a></span>
  </div>
</li>
      </ul>
</div><div class="item-list date">

        <span class="day">11</span>
    </h5>
    <ul>

      </ul>

  <h2><a href="/academics/music/node/" title=""></a></h2>


  <div class="content">

<!-- Layout -->

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Analysis of Romantic Musics</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>MUSC 1040 S01 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 16537]</span></h3>


  	This is an analysis course focusing on music of 19th -century Western concert tradition. The primary goal is to improve and introduce new analysis skills related to chromatic harmony and form. The course proceeds by distinctive genres, including examples of solo piano works, lieder, string quartets and other chamber works, symphonies, tone poems, and opera. Though the emphasis is primarily on analyzing purely musical elements, we will also touch on broader issues of Romantic aesthetics and cultural contexts, such as fragmentation, virtuosity, nostalgia, and the debate over absolute and programmatic music.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>16</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Lu+Wang">Lu Wang</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
					<dt>Meetings</dt>
									<dd>
						<span class="room"> </span>
						<span class="times">13:00 - 14:20 Tue, Thu - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017</span>
						</dd>
							
		
		
		
					<dt>Exam Group Code</dt>
			<dd>10</dd>
		


		</dl>
  </div>

							</div>

							
													</div><!-- end .second-column -->

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Sound Design</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>MUSC 1250 S01 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 16538]</span></h3>


  	This production seminar is a study of techniques and aesthetics used to create sonic environments and effects that enhance a variety of media including video, radio and audio art, new media, theater, and installation art. Technical topics include audio production in multi-channel formats, advanced audio editing, mixing and synthesis techniques, and audio system design. Enrollment limited to 12 students. Preference will be given to students who have completed MUSC 1200. Others will be evaluated for potential future work in the MEME program (Multimedia and Electronic Music Experiments) and past participation in MEME. Admission is determined by an entrance questionnaire completed at the first class meeting. Prereq: MUSC 1200.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>12</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=James+R+Moses">James R Moses</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
					<dt>Meetings</dt>
									<dd>
						<span class="room"> </span>
						<span class="times">14:30 - 15:50 Tue, Thu - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017</span>
						</dd>
							
		
		
		
					<dt>Exam Group Code</dt>
			<dd>03</dd>
		


		</dl>
  </div>

							</div>

                <span class="field-content"><a href="/academics/music/events/gregorio-uribe-brown-jazz-band">Gregorio Uribe with the Brown Jazz Band</a></span>
  </div>
</li>
      </ul>
</div><div class="item-list date">
    	    <h5><span class="month day-of-the-week">Nov</span>
        <span class="day">17</span>
    </h5>
    <ul>
          <li class="views-row views-row-1 views-row-odd views-row-first views-row-last">

      </ul>

      </ul>

						<section id="banner" class="marginator banner">
						
	
	<div id="block-ultibanner-0" class="clear-block block block-ultibanner ">
	
		
		<div class="content">
<article id="node-" class="main-article node node-unpublished">






  <h2><a href="/academics/music/node/" title=""></a></h2>


  <div class="content">
          </div>

	
  <div class="clear-block">

<!-- Layout -->

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Seminar in Electronic Music: Real-Time Systems</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>MUSC 1210 S01 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 16541]</span></h3>


  	Seminar in Electronic Music is a study of music employing electronic media, including real-time digital signal processing, multimedia, and live performance. Technical aspects of the course focus on programming using Max/MSP to create interactive projects and algorithmic compositions. Permission of instructor required. Interested students must come to the first class.  Preference will be given to students who have completed MUSC 0200.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>999</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Joseph+W+Rovan">Joseph W Rovan</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
					<dt>Meetings</dt>
									<dd>
						<span class="room"> </span>
						<span class="times">13:00 - 14:20 Tue, Thu - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017</span>
						</dd>
							
		
		
		
					<dt>Exam Group Code</dt>
			<dd>10</dd>
		


		</dl>
  </div>

							</div>

							
													</div><!-- end .second-column -->

<!-- Layout -->

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Seminar in Electronic Music: Real-Time Systems</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>MUSC 1210 L01 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 16542]</span></h3>


  	Seminar in Electronic Music is a study of music employing electronic media, including real-time digital signal processing, multimedia, and live performance. Technical aspects of the course focus on programming using Max/MSP to create interactive projects and algorithmic compositions. Permission of instructor required. Interested students must come to the first class.  Preference will be given to students who have completed MUSC 0200.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>999</dd>
		
		


		

	
					<dt>Meetings</dt>
									<dd>
						<span class="room"> </span>
						<span class="times">14:00 - 14:50 Fri - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017</span>
						</dd>
							
		
		
					<dt>Meeting Type</dt>
			<dd>L: Lab</dd>
		
		


		</dl>
  </div>

							</div>

							
													</div><!-- end .second-column -->

          <li class="views-row views-row-1 views-row-odd views-row-first views-row-last">  
  <div class="views-field-title">
                <span class="field-content"><a href="/academics/music/events/piano-workshop-39">Piano Workshop</a></span>
  </div>
</li>
      </ul>
</div><div class="item-list date">
    	    <h5><span class="month day-of-the-week">Dec</span>
        <span class="day">3</span>
    </h5>
    <ul>
          <li class="views-row views-row-1 views-row-odd views-row-first views-row-last">  
  <div class="views-field-title">
                <span class="field-content"><a href="/academics/music/events/lessons-carols">Lessons &amp; Carols</a></span>
  </div>

      </ul>
</div>    </div>

    View Full Calendar  </a>
</div>
  
  
  
</div> </div>
			
				
	</div>

						</div><!-- end .third-column -->
							
				</div><!-- end .marginator -->

						<section id="banner" class="marginator banner">
						
	
	<div id="block-ultibanner-0" class="clear-block block block-ultibanner ">
	
		
		<div class="content">
<article id="node-" class="main-article node node-unpublished">






  <h2><a href="/academics/music/node/" title=""></a></h2>


  <div class="content">
          </div>

	
  <div class="clear-block">
    <div class="meta">

			
	    
		</div><!-- end .meta -->
	</div>

</article>

	</div>

<!-- Layout -->

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Music and Identity</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>MUSC 2070 S01 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 16543]</span></h3>


  	From 19th-century European nationalism to 20th-century American multiculturalism, people have used music to affirm their identities. Drawing on anthropological and sociological theory, we examine the variety of connections between music and identity in several case studies. We consider the possible contributions of music to cross- cultural understanding, and discuss the ethics of musical border- crossing.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>16</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Marc+A+Perlman">Marc A Perlman</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
					<dt>Meetings</dt>
									<dd>
						<span class="room"> </span>
						<span class="times">16:00 - 18:30 Thu - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017</span>
						</dd>
							
		
		
		
					<dt>Exam Group Code</dt>
			<dd>04</dd>
		


		</dl>
  </div>

							</div>

							
													</div><!-- end .second-column -->

  <h2><a href="/academics/music/node/" title=""></a></h2>


  <div class="content">

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Critical Improvisation Studies</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>MUSC 2300A S01 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 16549]</span></h3>


  	Advanced seminar exploring improvisation from various perspectives: historical, anthropological, philosophical, ethical, and creative. We study improvisation in diverse musical traditions, in other arts, and in problem-solving contexts such as business, technology, and games. Discussion topics include individual vs. group improvisation, the status of "freedom" in creative processes, and the social and artistic functions of improvisation. Instructor permission required.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>40</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Dana+A+Gooley">Dana A Gooley</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
					<dt>Meetings</dt>
									<dd>
						<span class="room"> </span>
						<span class="times">15:00 - 17:30 Mon - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017</span>
						</dd>
							
		
		
		
					<dt>Exam Group Code</dt>
			<dd>15</dd>
		


		</dl>
  </div>

							</div>

		<section id="content-bottom">

  <h2>Spotlight</h2>

<article id="node-" class="main-article node node-unpublished">






  <h2><a href="/academics/music/node/" title=""></a></h2>


  <div class="content">
          </div>

<!-- Layout -->

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Ethnography of Popular Music</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>MUSC 2080B S01 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 16555]</span></h3>


  	This seminar explores ethnographic work on popular music, including scholarship rooted in ethnomusicology, sociology, and performance studies. We will discuss case studies from around the world and will compare contemporary ethnographic research with other approaches to popular music (e.g., Frankfurt School critical theory, Birmingham School cultural studies, and text-oriented popular music studies). Prerequisite: graduate standing or written permission.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>24</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Kiri+M+Miller">Kiri M Miller</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
					<dt>Meetings</dt>
									<dd>
						<span class="room"> </span>
						<span class="times">15:00 - 17:30 Wed - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017</span>
						</dd>
							
		
		
		
					<dt>Exam Group Code</dt>
			<dd>17</dd>
		


		</dl>
  </div>

							</div>

							
													</div><!-- end .second-column -->

					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Digital Performance</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>MUSC 2210 S01 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 16558]</span></h3>


  	A production seminar examining the artistic impact and creative potential of digital media in the context of live performance. Readings and analysis of work examine innovations in performance practice from dance, theatre, performance art and music. Collaborative assignments investigate video projection, sound design and interactive sensor technology, culminating in a final large-scale performance. Permission will be granted based upon a questionnaire given in the first class.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>40</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Todd+E+Winkler">Todd E Winkler</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
					<dt>Meetings</dt>
									<dd>
						<span class="room"> </span>
						<span class="times">14:00 - 18:00 Wed - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017</span>
						</dd>
							
		
		
		
					<dt>Exam Group Code</dt>
			<dd>17</dd>
		


		</dl>
  </div>

							</div>

		<section id="content-bottom">
			
<div id="spotlight" class="clear-block block block-views the-bar">

  <h2>Spotlight</h2>
  <div class="content"><div class="view view-thebar view-id-thebar view-display-id-block_1 view-dom-id-3">
    
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
      <ul class="jcarousel jcarousel-view--thebar--block-1 jcarousel-dom-1 jcarousel-skin-default">
      <li class="jcarousel-item-1 odd">  
  <div class="views-field-field-bar-image-fid">
                <span class="field-content"><a href="http://www.browndailyherald.com/2017/10/03/lumen-gallery-provide-new-meditative-space-granoff/"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/music/sites/brown.edu.academics.music/files/imagecache/bar_item_image/bar-items/images/granoff-650x397.jpg" alt="" title="" width="160" height="90" class="imagecache imagecache-bar_item_image imagecache-default imagecache-bar_item_image_default"/></a></span>
  </div>
  
  <div class="views-field-tid">
                <span class="field-content">In The News</span>
  </div>
  
  <div class="views-field-title">
                <span class="field-content"><a href="http://www.browndailyherald.com/2017/10/03/lumen-gallery-provide-new-meditative-space-granoff/">‘Lumen’ gallery to provide new meditative space in Granoff</a></span>
  </div>
</li>
  </ul>
    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div> </div>

  
    <style type="text/css">
      .view-thebar .jcarousel-skin-default .jcarousel-clip-horizontal, .view-thebar .jcarousel-skin-default .jcarousel-container-horizontal {
        width: 180px; /* each item is 157px + 23px of padding/margin */
      }

        height: 225px;

        margin-top: -20px;

    </style>
  <![endif]-->
</div>
	</section>

						<section id="banner" class="marginator banner">
						
	
	<div id="block-ultibanner-0" class="clear-block block block-ultibanner ">
	
		
		<div class="content">
<article id="node-" class="main-article node node-unpublished">






  <h2><a href="/academics/music/node/" title=""></a></h2>


  <div class="content">
          </div>

	
  <div class="clear-block">
    <div class="meta">

			
	    
		</div><!-- end .meta -->
	</div>

</article>

<!-- Layout -->

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Reading Jazz</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>MUSC 0021B S01 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 16559]</span></h3>


  	This course will explore the musical aesthetics of jazz in texts about its world.  Students will listen to music and read poetry, fiction, autobiography and criticism to investigate techniques (including improvisation, rhythm, timbre and articulation), which authors such as Langston Hughes, Ralph Ellison, Charles Mingus, Stanley Crouch and Jack Kerouac employed to describe and support a creative community. Enrollment limited to 20 first year students. FYS DPLL WRIT
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>20</dd>
		
					<dt>Course Attributes</dt>
						<dd></dd>
			
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Matthew+R+McGarrell">Matthew R McGarrell</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
					<dt>Meetings</dt>
									<dd>
						<span class="room"> </span>
						<span class="times">16:00 - 18:30 Thu - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017</span>
						</dd>
							
		
		
		
					<dt>Exam Group Code</dt>
			<dd>04</dd>
		


		</dl>
  </div>

							</div>

							
													</div><!-- end .second-column -->
						
													<div id="sidebar-left" class="sidebar first-column column">
								
	
	<div id="block-menu-primary-links" class="clear-block block block-menu ">
	
		
		<div class="content"><ul class="menu"><li class="leaf first menu-home"><a href="/academics/music/news" title="Home">Home</a></li>
<li class="collapsed menu-about"><a href="/academics/music/about" title="">About</a></li>

<li class="collapsed menu-graduate"><a href="/academics/music/graduate" title="Graduate">Graduate</a></li>
<li class="leaf active-trail menu-courses"><a href="/academics/music/courses" title="Display Department Course Information">Courses</a></li>
<li class="collapsed menu-ensemblesandlessons"><a href="/academics/music/ensembles-and-lessons" title="Ensembles and Lessons">Ensembles and Lessons</a></li>

	<div id="block-brown_social_media-0" class="clear-block block block-brown_social_media ">
	
		
		<div class="content">		<div id = "brown-social-media">
			<p class="social-media-connected">Stay Connected with <br />Music</p>

					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Brazilian Choro Ensemble</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>MUSC 0645 S01 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 16560]</span></h3>


  	Half credit each semester. Students will play this popular Brazilian style, which emerged in the late 19th century and is often compared to early jazz. Classes run according to the traditional roda model, a structured jam session where performers read through, improvise upon, and hone their abilities to play familiar tunes. Prior familiarity with choro music not required, but some instrumental expertise is. Ability to read notation preferred. Typical instruments include guitar, cavaquinho (Brazilian ukulele), mandolin, flute, and pandeiro (Brazilian tambourine), but others may participate on instructor approval. Enrollment limit 20.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>0.5</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>20</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Christopher+J+Tucker">Christopher J Tucker</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
					<dt>Meetings</dt>
									<dd>
						<span class="room"> </span>
						<span class="times">17:30 - 19:00 Mon - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017</span>
						</dd>
							
		
		
		
					<dt>Exam Group Code</dt>
			<dd>15</dd>
		


		</dl>
  </div>

  <h2>Spotlight</h2>
  <div class="content"><div class="view view-thebar view-id-thebar view-display-id-block_1 view-dom-id-3">

        width: 180px; /* each item is 157px + 23px of padding/margin */
      }
      .view-thebar .jcarousel-skin-default .jcarousel-clip-vertical, .view-thebar .jcarousel-skin-default .jcarousel-container-vertical {
        height: 225px;

        height: 205px;
      }
  </style>
  <!--[if lt IE 10]>
    <style type="text/css">
      .view-thebar {
        margin-top: -20px;
      }
    </style>
  <![endif]-->
</div>
	</section>
	

    </div><!-- End #wrapper -->

	<div id="block-ultibanner-0" class="clear-block block block-ultibanner ">
	
		
		<div class="content">
<article id="node-" class="main-article node node-unpublished">






  <h2><a href="/academics/music/node/" title=""></a></h2>


  <div class="content">
          </div>

	
  <div class="clear-block">
    <div class="meta">

			
	    
		</div><!-- end .meta -->
	</div>

<!-- Layout -->

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Javanese Gamelan</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>MUSC 0650 S01 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 16563]</span></h3>


  	Half credit each semester. Instruction, rehearsals, and performances in the gamelan music of Java, on instruments owned by the department. No prerequisites.  Enrollment limited to 18 students.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>0.5</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>18</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Marc+A+Perlman">Marc A Perlman</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
					<dt>Meetings</dt>
									<dd>
						<span class="room"> </span>
						<span class="times">18:00 - 21:00 Tue - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017</span>
						</dd>
							
		
		
		
					<dt>Exam Group Code</dt>
			<dd>09</dd>
		


		</dl>
  </div>

							</div>

							
													</div><!-- end .second-column -->
						
													<div id="sidebar-left" class="sidebar first-column column">

					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Theory of Tonal Music</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>MUSC 0550 L01 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 16742]</span></h3>


  	Prerequisite to music concentration. For students with knowledge of rudiments of music, including scales, intervals, key signatures, rhythm, and meter. Knowledge of keyboard strongly recommended. Intensive study of voice leading and tonal harmony; analysis, ear training, sight singing, keyboard exercises. An entrance exam will be administered in Orwig 315 at the first regular class meeting. Students intending to enroll in MUSC 0550 must pass this test. Experienced instrumentalists or singers who have facility sight reading music normally place into MUSC0550. MUSC0400 is appropriate for students who need training in the rudiments to prepare for MUSC0550. MUSC0550 is prerequisite to MUSC0560.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>65</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Arlene+M+Cole">Arlene M Cole</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
					<dt>Meetings</dt>
									<dd>
						<span class="room"> </span>
						<span class="times">09:00 - 09:50 Mon, Wed, Fri - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017</span>
						</dd>
							
		
		
					<dt>Meeting Type</dt>
			<dd>L: Lab</dd>
		
		


		</dl>
  </div>

							</div>

				<div id="brown-footer" class="clear-block block block-block ">

<article id="node-" class="main-article node node-unpublished">






  <h2><a href="/academics/music/node/" title=""></a></h2>


  <div class="content">
          </div>

<!-- Layout -->

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Theory of Tonal Music</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>MUSC 0550 L02 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 16763]</span></h3>


  	Prerequisite to music concentration. For students with knowledge of rudiments of music, including scales, intervals, key signatures, rhythm, and meter. Knowledge of keyboard strongly recommended. Intensive study of voice leading and tonal harmony; analysis, ear training, sight singing, keyboard exercises. An entrance exam will be administered in Orwig 315 at the first regular class meeting. Students intending to enroll in MUSC 0550 must pass this test. Experienced instrumentalists or singers who have facility sight reading music normally place into MUSC0550. MUSC0400 is appropriate for students who need training in the rudiments to prepare for MUSC0550. MUSC0550 is prerequisite to MUSC0560.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>65</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Arlene+M+Cole">Arlene M Cole</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
					<dt>Meetings</dt>
									<dd>
						<span class="room"> </span>
						<span class="times">12:00 - 12:50 Mon, Wed, Fri - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017</span>
						</dd>
							
		
		
					<dt>Meeting Type</dt>
			<dd>L: Lab</dd>
		
		


		</dl>
  </div>

							</div>

							
													</div><!-- end .second-column -->

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Introduction to Music Theory</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>MUSC 0400 S01 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 16769]</span></h3>


  	An introduction to musical terms, elements, and techniques, including notation, intervals, scales and modes, triads and seventh chords, modulation, melody writing and harmonization, analysis, and composition. Ear-training and sight-singing are included. For students with some musical training. Enrollment limited to 40.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>40</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Linda+Jiorle-Nagy">Linda Jiorle-Nagy</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
					<dt>Meetings</dt>
									<dd>
						<span class="room"> </span>
						<span class="times">11:00 - 11:50 Mon, Wed, Fri - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017</span>
						</dd>
							
		
		
		
					<dt>Exam Group Code</dt>
			<dd>16</dd>
		


		</dl>
  </div>

							</div>

		<div class="content">
<article id="node-" class="main-article node node-unpublished">






  <h2><a href="/academics/music/node/" title=""></a></h2>


  <div class="content">
          </div>

	
  <div class="clear-block">
    <div class="meta">

			
	    
		</div><!-- end .meta -->
	</div>

<!-- Layout -->

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Electroacoustic Improv Ensemble</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>MUSC 0220 S01 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 16770]</span></h3>


  	An ensemble devoted to free improvisation with new media. Experimental approaches to sound and focused listening techniques are explored with acoustic instruments, live electronics, real-time video, together with networked improvisation, and more. Enrollment limited to 12 students; by audition.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>0.5</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>12</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Alexander+P+Dupuis">Alexander P Dupuis</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
					<dt>Meetings</dt>
									<dd>
						<span class="room"> </span>
						<span class="times">19:00 - 21:50 Wed - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017</span>
						</dd>
							
		
		
		
					<dt>Exam Group Code</dt>
			<dd>02</dd>
		


		</dl>
  </div>

							</div>

							
													</div><!-- end .second-column -->
						
													<div id="sidebar-left" class="sidebar first-column column">

	<div id="block-views-contact_information-block_1" class="clear-block block block-views ">
	
		
		<div class="content"><div class="view view-contact-information view-id-contact_information view-display-id-block_1 view-dom-id-1">
    
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="views-row views-row-1 views-row-odd views-row-first views-row-last">
    <div class="vcard">
	<div class="adr">
		<div class="org">
		 <div class="organization-name">Brown University</div>

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Chorus</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>MUSC 0600 S01 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 16771]</span></h3>


  	Half credit each semester. A practical study of choral literature, techniques, and performance practice from Gregorian chant to the present, offered through rehearsals, sectionals, and performance. Enrollment is by audition, based on voice quality, experience, and music-reading ability. Instructor permission required.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>0.5</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>106</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Louis+F+Jodry">Louis F Jodry</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
					<dt>Meetings</dt>
									<dd>
						<span class="room"> </span>
						<span class="times">18:30 - 20:20 Mon, Wed - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017</span>
						</dd>
							
		
		
		
					<dt>Exam Group Code</dt>
			<dd>02</dd>
		


		</dl>
  </div>

							</div>

	<div id="block-ultibanner-0" class="clear-block block block-ultibanner ">
	
		
		<div class="content">
<article id="node-" class="main-article node node-unpublished">






  <h2><a href="/academics/music/node/" title=""></a></h2>


  <div class="content">
          </div>

	
  <div class="clear-block">
    <div class="meta">

			
	    
		</div><!-- end .meta -->
	</div>

<!-- Layout -->

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Orchestra</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>MUSC 0610 S01 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 16772]</span></h3>


  	Half credit each semester. A practical study of the orchestra repertory from Bach to the present, offered through coaching, rehearsals, and performances. Enrollment is by audition. Students will be notified of audition results within the first seven days of the semester. Restricted to skilled instrumentalists.  May be repeated for credit.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>0.5</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>999</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Brandon+K+Brown">Brandon K Brown</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
					<dt>Meetings</dt>
									<dd>
						<span class="room"> </span>
						<span class="times">19:15 - 21:45 Tue, Thu - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017</span>
						</dd>
							
		
		
		
					<dt>Exam Group Code</dt>
			<dd>02</dd>
		


		</dl>
  </div>

							</div>

							
													</div><!-- end .second-column -->
						
													<div id="sidebar-left" class="sidebar first-column column">

	<div id="block-views-contact_information-block_1" class="clear-block block block-views ">
	
		
		<div class="content"><div class="view view-contact-information view-id-contact_information view-display-id-block_1 view-dom-id-1">
    
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="views-row views-row-1 views-row-odd views-row-first views-row-last">
    <div class="vcard">
	<div class="adr">
		<div class="org">
		 <div class="organization-name">Brown University</div>

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Wind Symphony</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>MUSC 0620 S01 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 16776]</span></h3>


  	Half credit each semester. A practical study of the wind band repertory from Mozart to the present, offered through coaching, rehearsals, and performances. Enrollment is by audition. Restricted to skilled instrumentalists. Instructor permission required.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>0.5</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>140</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Matthew+R+McGarrell">Matthew R McGarrell</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
					<dt>Meetings</dt>
														<dd>
						<div class="room"><a href="http://www.brown.edu/Facilities/Facilities_Management/maps/index.php?query=Grant Recital">Grant Recital</a> 105</div>
						<div class="times">18:00 - 19:20 Mon - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017						</div>
						</dd>
											<dd>
						<div class="room"><a href="http://www.brown.edu/Facilities/Facilities_Management/maps/index.php?query=Grant Recital">Grant Recital</a> 105</div>
						<div class="times">18:00 - 20:20 Wed - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017						</div>
						</dd>
												
		
		
		
					<dt>Exam Group Code</dt>
			<dd>02</dd>
		


		</dl>
  </div>

							</div>

							
													</div><!-- end .second-column -->

<article id="node-" class="main-article node node-unpublished">






  <h2><a href="/academics/music/node/" title=""></a></h2>


  <div class="content">
          </div>

	
  <div class="clear-block">

<!-- Layout -->

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Jazz Band</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>MUSC 0630 S01 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 16778]</span></h3>


  	Half credit each semester. A practical study of jazz from the 1920s to the present through coaching, rehearsals, and performance. Seminars on arranging, ear training, and improvisation are conducted for interested students but the focus is on performance. Enrollment is by audition. Restricted to skilled instrumentalists and vocalists. Instructor permission required.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>0.5</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>140</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Matthew+R+McGarrell">Matthew R McGarrell</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
					<dt>Meetings</dt>
														<dd>
						<div class="room"><a href="http://www.brown.edu/Facilities/Facilities_Management/maps/index.php?query=Grant Recital">Grant Recital</a> 105</div>
						<div class="times">18:10 - 19:20 Thu - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017						</div>
						</dd>
											<dd>
						<div class="room"><a href="http://www.brown.edu/Facilities/Facilities_Management/maps/index.php?query=Grant Recital">Grant Recital</a> 105</div>
						<div class="times">19:30 - 20:50 Mon - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017						</div>
						</dd>
												
		
		
		
					<dt>Exam Group Code</dt>
			<dd>15</dd>
		


		</dl>
  </div>

							</div>

							
													</div><!-- end .second-column -->

				<div id="content">

					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Jazz Band</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>MUSC 0630 S02 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 16779]</span></h3>


  	Half credit each semester. A practical study of jazz from the 1920s to the present through coaching, rehearsals, and performance. Seminars on arranging, ear training, and improvisation are conducted for interested students but the focus is on performance. Enrollment is by audition. Restricted to skilled instrumentalists and vocalists. Instructor permission required.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>0.5</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>40</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Matthew+R+McGarrell">Matthew R McGarrell</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
					<dt>Meetings</dt>
									<dd>
						<span class="room"> </span>
						<span class="times">20:00 - 21:20 Tue - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017</span>
						</dd>
							
		
		
		
					<dt>Exam Group Code</dt>
			<dd>04</dd>
		


		</dl>
  </div>

							</div>

		<div class="content">
<article id="node-" class="main-article node node-unpublished">






  <h2><a href="/academics/music/node/" title=""></a></h2>


  <div class="content">
          </div>

	
  <div class="clear-block">
    <div class="meta">

			
	    
		</div><!-- end .meta -->
	</div>

<!-- Layout -->

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Jazz Band</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>MUSC 0630 S03 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 16780]</span></h3>


  	Half credit each semester. A practical study of jazz from the 1920s to the present through coaching, rehearsals, and performance. Seminars on arranging, ear training, and improvisation are conducted for interested students but the focus is on performance. Enrollment is by audition. Restricted to skilled instrumentalists and vocalists. Instructor permission required.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>0.5</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>40</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Matthew+R+McGarrell">Matthew R McGarrell</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
					<dt>Meetings</dt>
									<dd>
						<span class="room"> </span>
						<span class="times">14:00 - 15:20 Wed - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017</span>
						</dd>
							
		
		
		
					<dt>Exam Group Code</dt>
			<dd>07</dd>
		


		</dl>
  </div>

							</div>

							
													</div><!-- end .second-column -->
						
													<div id="sidebar-left" class="sidebar first-column column">

	<div id="block-views-contact_information-block_1" class="clear-block block block-views ">
	
		
		<div class="content"><div class="view view-contact-information view-id-contact_information view-display-id-block_1 view-dom-id-1">
    
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="views-row views-row-1 views-row-odd views-row-first views-row-last">
    <div class="vcard">
	<div class="adr">
		<div class="org">

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Jazz Band</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>MUSC 0630 S04 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 16781]</span></h3>


  	Half credit each semester. A practical study of jazz from the 1920s to the present through coaching, rehearsals, and performance. Seminars on arranging, ear training, and improvisation are conducted for interested students but the focus is on performance. Enrollment is by audition. Restricted to skilled instrumentalists and vocalists. Instructor permission required.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>0.5</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>40</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Matthew+R+McGarrell">Matthew R McGarrell</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
					<dt>Meetings</dt>
									<dd>
						<span class="room"> </span>
						<span class="times">16:00 - 17:20 Wed - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017</span>
						</dd>
							
		
		
		
					<dt>Exam Group Code</dt>
			<dd>17</dd>
		


		</dl>
  </div>

							</div>

		<div class="content">
<article id="node-" class="main-article node node-unpublished">






  <h2><a href="/academics/music/node/" title=""></a></h2>


  <div class="content">
          </div>

	
  <div class="clear-block">
    <div class="meta">

			
	    
		</div><!-- end .meta -->
	</div>

<!-- Layout -->

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Jazz Band</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>MUSC 0630 S05 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 16782]</span></h3>


  	Half credit each semester. A practical study of jazz from the 1920s to the present through coaching, rehearsals, and performance. Seminars on arranging, ear training, and improvisation are conducted for interested students but the focus is on performance. Enrollment is by audition. Restricted to skilled instrumentalists and vocalists. Instructor permission required.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>0.5</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>40</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Matthew+R+McGarrell">Matthew R McGarrell</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
					<dt>Meetings</dt>
									<dd>
						<span class="room"> </span>
						<span class="times">16:00 - 17:20 Fri - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017</span>
						</dd>
							
		
		
		
					<dt>Exam Group Code</dt>
			<dd>11</dd>
		


		</dl>
  </div>

							</div>

							
													</div><!-- end .second-column -->
						
													<div id="sidebar-left" class="sidebar first-column column">

	<div id="block-views-contact_information-block_1" class="clear-block block block-views ">
	
		
		<div class="content"><div class="view view-contact-information view-id-contact_information view-display-id-block_1 view-dom-id-1">
    
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="views-row views-row-1 views-row-odd views-row-first views-row-last">
    <div class="vcard">
	<div class="adr">
		<div class="org">
		 <div class="organization-name">Brown University</div>

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Ghanaian Drumming and Dancing Ensemble</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>MUSC 0640 S01 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 16786]</span></h3>


  	A dynamic introductory course on drumming, dancing, and singing of Ghana and the diaspora.  Students learn to perform diverse types of African music, including Ewe, Akan, Ga, and Dagomba pieces on drums, bells, and shakers.  No prerequisites.  May be repeated for credit.  Enrollment limited to 15. Instructor permission required.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>0.5</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>15</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Martin+K+Obeng">Martin K Obeng</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
					<dt>Meetings</dt>
									<dd>
						<span class="room"> </span>
						<span class="times">17:00 - 19:20 Wed - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017</span>
						</dd>
							
		
		
		
					<dt>Exam Group Code</dt>
			<dd>17</dd>
		


		</dl>
  </div>

							</div>

		<div class="content">
<article id="node-" class="main-article node node-unpublished">






  <h2><a href="/academics/music/node/" title=""></a></h2>


  <div class="content">
          </div>

	
  <div class="clear-block">
    <div class="meta">

			
	    
		</div><!-- end .meta -->

<!-- Layout -->

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">World Music Ensemble</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>MUSC 0642 S01 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 16787]</span></h3>


  	This ensemble focuses on global percussive and song traditions, especially those of the African diaspora (based on instructor's vast musical experiences). Here western instrumentalists fuse with traditional musicians from every culture: bongo, gyil, ukulele, tabla, etc. Students will grow and develop their musical skills by learning new techniques on their own instrument, exploring a range of repertoire representing genres such as highlife, reggae, salsa, afrobeat, Afro-jazz, and global fusions. There will be unique opportunities to work on improvisation taking influence from Steve Reich, Tito Puente, Randy Weston, Hugh Masekela, Paul Simon, Miriam Makeba, Ghanaba, and Milton Nasimiento. DPLL
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>0.5</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>18</dd>
		
					<dt>Course Attributes</dt>
						<dd>Diverse Perspectives in LL</dd>
			
		


																	
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Martin+K+Obeng">Martin K Obeng</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
											
	<dt>Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Esther+V+Kurtz">Esther V Kurtz</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
									
			

	
					<dt>Meetings</dt>
									<dd>
						<span class="room"> </span>
						<span class="times">19:00 - 21:00 Mon - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017</span>
						</dd>
							
		
		
		
					<dt>Exam Group Code</dt>
			<dd>02</dd>
		


		</dl>
  </div>

							</div>

							
													</div><!-- end .second-column -->

  <h2><a href="/academics/music/node/" title=""></a></h2>


  <div class="content">

<!-- Layout -->

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Old-Time String Band</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>MUSC 0670 S01 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 16788]</span></h3>


  	Half course each semester. Instruction and ensemble playing. Music taught by ear. American (southern Appalachian Mountain) traditional music on violin (fiddle), 5-string banjo, mandolin, and guitar.  Enrollment limited to 20 students.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>0.5</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>20</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Sandol+E+Astrausky">Sandol E Astrausky</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
					<dt>Meetings</dt>
									<dd>
						<span class="room"> </span>
						<span class="times">19:00 - 20:50 Tue - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017</span>
						</dd>
							
		
		
		
					<dt>Exam Group Code</dt>
			<dd>05</dd>
		


		</dl>
  </div>

							</div>

							
													</div><!-- end .second-column -->

		<div class="content">
<article id="node-" class="main-article node node-unpublished">






  <h2><a href="/academics/music/node/" title=""></a></h2>


  <div class="content">
          </div>

	
  <div class="clear-block">
    <div class="meta">

<!-- Layout -->

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Chamber Music Performance</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>MUSC 0680 S01 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 16789]</span></h3>


  	Half credit each semester. The practical study of the literature of chamber music through participation in a small ensemble. Regular rehearsals, coaching by department staff, and performances are required. Enrollment is by audition.  Students will be notified of audition results within the first ten days of the semester. Restricted to skilled instrumentalists.  May be repeated for credit.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>0.5</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>999</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Lois+Finkel">Lois Finkel</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
				
		
		
		
		


		</dl>
  </div>

							</div>

							
													</div><!-- end .second-column -->
						
													<div id="sidebar-left" class="sidebar first-column column">

		<div class="content"><div class="view view-contact-information view-id-contact_information view-display-id-block_1 view-dom-id-1">
    
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="views-row views-row-1 views-row-odd views-row-first views-row-last">
    <div class="vcard">
	<div class="adr">
		<div class="org">

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Advanced Ghanaian Drumming and Dancing Ensemble</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>MUSC 1960 S01 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 16794]</span></h3>


  	Students with experience in African and related musical traditions perform drumming, dancing, and singing of Ghana and the diaspora.  Focus on a more challenging repertoire with emphasis on multi-part, lead, and improvisational playing. Prerequisite:  audition. May be repeatable for credit.  Instructor permission required.  Enrollment limited to 15 students.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>0.5</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>15</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Martin+K+Obeng">Martin K Obeng</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
					<dt>Meetings</dt>
									<dd>
						<span class="room"> </span>
						<span class="times">19:30 - 21:50 Wed - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017</span>
						</dd>
							
		
		
		
					<dt>Exam Group Code</dt>
			<dd>02</dd>
		


		</dl>
  </div>

							</div>

<article id="node-" class="main-article node node-unpublished">






  <h2><a href="/academics/music/node/" title=""></a></h2>


  <div class="content">
          </div>

<!-- Layout -->

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Music in the Andean Countries: From Cumbia to Carnavalito</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>MUSC 1923 S01 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 17105]</span></h3>


  	This course provides an introduction to the music of South America’s Andean countries. Through texts, listenings, and hands-on instruction, students will explore the social histories and stylistic principles of genres like Colombian and Peruvian cumbia, Afro-Peruvian festejo and landó, Chilean nueva canción, and the sikuri and huayno music of South Andean Quechua and Aymara peoples. Class sessions balance cultural analysis with opportunities to play, and students are expected to develop some facility with key songs and rhythms. No experience is necessary, though inexperienced musicians can expect to focus on instrumental or vocal parts that present a lower bar to participation.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>16</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Christopher+J+Tucker">Christopher J Tucker</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
					<dt>Meetings</dt>
									<dd>
						<span class="room"> </span>
						<span class="times">10:30 - 11:50 Tue, Thu - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017</span>
						</dd>
							
		
		
		
					<dt>Exam Group Code</dt>
			<dd>13</dd>
		


		</dl>
  </div>

							</div>

							
													</div><!-- end .second-column -->

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Timbre in Electroacoustic Music</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>MUSC 2235 S01 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 17146]</span></h3>


  	We will investiage the topic of timbre in electroacoustic music though both analysis and composition. We will study musical compositions in various media (acoustic and electronic) that use timbre in various ways, scholarly writing that looks in more depth at compositional processes involving timbre (such as in Spectral music), and various software programs that can assist in analysis and composition. Students will compose new works for electronics alone, as well as for guest solo performers with interactive electronics to be performed in a public concert. Enrollment limited to 8. Permission required for undergraduates.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>8</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Eric+T+Nathan">Eric T Nathan</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
					<dt>Meetings</dt>
									<dd>
						<span class="room"> </span>
						<span class="times">16:00 - 18:30 Thu - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017</span>
						</dd>
							
		
		
		
					<dt>Exam Group Code</dt>
			<dd>04</dd>
		


		</dl>
  </div>

							</div>

				<div id="brown-footer" class="clear-block block block-block ">

<article id="node-" class="main-article node node-unpublished">






  <h2><a href="/academics/music/node/" title=""></a></h2>


  <div class="content">
          </div>

	
  <div class="clear-block">
    <div class="meta">

<!-- Layout -->

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Key Concepts in Sociocultural Theory</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>MUSC 2080H S01 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 17305]</span></h3>


  	Ethnomusicology has always been interdisciplinary, and is becoming more so.  The student today may encounter concepts from semiotics, linguistics, cultural studies, literary theory, political economy, sociology, cognitive psychology, media studies, sound studies, science and technology studies, organizational studies, and material culture studies, and other disciplines as well.  We will examine some of the key concepts of these fields and consider their possible uses in the study of the performing arts.  From ‘affordances’ to the ‘type/token distinction,’ from ‘actor-network theory’ to the ‘third-person effect,’ we will learn to apply (and criticize) concepts presupposed by much current socio-cultural theorizing.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>24</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Marc+A+Perlman">Marc A Perlman</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
					<dt>Meetings</dt>
									<dd>
						<span class="room"> </span>
						<span class="times">12:00 - 14:30 Mon - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017</span>
						</dd>
							
		
		
		
					<dt>Exam Group Code</dt>
			<dd>15</dd>
		


		</dl>
  </div>

							</div>

							
													</div><!-- end .second-column -->

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Introduction to Music Theory</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>MUSC 0400 S02 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 17311]</span></h3>


  	An introduction to musical terms, elements, and techniques, including notation, intervals, scales and modes, triads and seventh chords, modulation, melody writing and harmonization, analysis, and composition. Ear-training and sight-singing are included. For students with some musical training. Enrollment limited to 40.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>40</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Samuel+E+Zerin">Samuel E Zerin</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
					<dt>Meetings</dt>
									<dd>
						<span class="room"> </span>
						<span class="times">10:00 - 10:50 Mon, Wed, Fri - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017</span>
						</dd>
							
		
		
		
					<dt>Exam Group Code</dt>
			<dd>14</dd>
		


		</dl>
  </div>

							</div>

						<section id="banner" class="marginator banner">
						
	
	<div id="block-ultibanner-0" class="clear-block block block-ultibanner ">
	
		
		<div class="content">



	<!--div id="node-3014" class="ultibanner banner"-->
		<img  class="imagefield imagefield-field_ultibanner_image" width="940" height="200" alt="" src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/music/sites/brown.edu.academics.music/files/ultibanner/Undergraduate-Header-940x200_0.jpg?1501098004" />	<!--/div-->
