<!-- Layout -->

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Courses for Fall 2017</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								<div class="content">



		<div class="course-section" id="MUSC">
			
				<ul class="course-list">
										<li id="MUSC0021B">
					<h4>Reading Jazz</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">This course will explore the musical aesthetics of jazz in texts about its world.  Students will listen to music and read poetry, fiction, autobiography and criticism to investigate techniques (including improvisation, rhythm, timbre and articulation), which authors such as Langston Hughes, Ralph Ellison, Charles Mingus, Stanley Crouch and Jack Kerouac employed to describe and support a creative community. Enrollment limited to 20 first year students. FYS DPLL WRIT </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/music/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=16559">MUSC 0021B S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>McGarrell</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="MUSC0021J">
					<h4>Stephen Sondheim and the American Musical</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">This seminar considers the theater shows of Stephen Sondheim in relation to the history of the American musical. Through close study of selected scenes and shows, we examine how and why Sondheim and his collaborators “reinvented” the genre. Special emphasis will be given to Sondheim's critical skepticism concerning the myths, characters, and ethos of social optimism that have been central to the Broadway tradition. We examine links between the shows and post-WWII historical contexts, and consider the political implications of the circumscribed social universe—predominantly white, urban, and affluent—within which most of his shows take place. FYS </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/music/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=16535">MUSC 0021J S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Gooley</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="MUSC0200">
					<h4>Computers and Music</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">Examine the history, literature, production and theory of music technology. Track development of musical inventions and their impact on musical thought, production and culture. Develop theoretical and practical knowledge of computer music based on first-hand experience in the Multimedia Lab, using computer music software and hardware to complete creative assignments. Gain an appreciation for the pioneering work done in previous decades, both in research and composition. Become familiar with the literature of electronic music and learn about the impact of technology on popular and experimental genres. Permission granted based on questionnaire given in first class. Preference given to lower-level students. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/music/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=16533">MUSC 0200 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Winkler</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="MUSC0220">
					<h4>Electroacoustic Improv Ensemble</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">An ensemble devoted to free improvisation with new media. Experimental approaches to sound and focused listening techniques are explored with acoustic instruments, live electronics, real-time video, together with networked improvisation, and more. Enrollment limited to 12 students; by audition. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/music/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=16770">MUSC 0220 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Dupuis</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="MUSC0400">
					<h4>Introduction to Music Theory</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">An introduction to musical terms, elements, and techniques, including notation, intervals, scales and modes, triads and seventh chords, modulation, melody writing and harmonization, analysis, and composition. Ear-training and sight-singing are included. For students with some musical training. Enrollment limited to 40. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/music/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=16769">MUSC 0400 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Jiorle-Nagy</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																				<div class="additional-sections">
															
																		
												<div class="section">

				</li>
										<li id="MUSC0550">
					<h4>Theory of Tonal Music</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">Prerequisite to music concentration. For students with knowledge of rudiments of music, including scales, intervals, key signatures, rhythm, and meter. Knowledge of keyboard strongly recommended. Intensive study of voice leading and tonal harmony; analysis, ear training, sight singing, keyboard exercises. An entrance exam will be administered in Orwig 315 at the first regular class meeting. Students intending to enroll in MUSC 0550 must pass this test. Experienced instrumentalists or singers who have facility sight reading music normally place into MUSC0550. MUSC0400 is appropriate for students who need training in the rudiments to prepare for MUSC0550. MUSC0550 is prerequisite to MUSC0560. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">

										<li id="MUSC0600">
					<h4>Chorus</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">Half credit each semester. A practical study of choral literature, techniques, and performance practice from Gregorian chant to the present, offered through rehearsals, sectionals, and performance. Enrollment is by audition, based on voice quality, experience, and music-reading ability. Instructor permission required. </div>

										<li id="MUSC0610">
					<h4>Orchestra</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">Half credit each semester. A practical study of the orchestra repertory from Bach to the present, offered through coaching, rehearsals, and performances. Enrollment is by audition. Students will be notified of audition results within the first seven days of the semester. Restricted to skilled instrumentalists.  May be repeated for credit. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">

					<h4>Wind Symphony</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">Half credit each semester. A practical study of the wind band repertory from Mozart to the present, offered through coaching, rehearsals, and performances. Enrollment is by audition. Restricted to skilled instrumentalists. Instructor permission required. </div>

										<li id="MUSC0630">
					<h4>Jazz Band</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">Half credit each semester. A practical study of jazz from the 1920s to the present through coaching, rehearsals, and performance. Seminars on arranging, ear training, and improvisation are conducted for interested students but the focus is on performance. Enrollment is by audition. Restricted to skilled instrumentalists and vocalists. Instructor permission required. </div>

										<li id="MUSC0640">
					<h4>Ghanaian Drumming and Dancing Ensemble</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">A dynamic introductory course on drumming, dancing, and singing of Ghana and the diaspora.  Students learn to perform diverse types of African music, including Ewe, Akan, Ga, and Dagomba pieces on drums, bells, and shakers.  No prerequisites.  May be repeated for credit.  Enrollment limited to 15. Instructor permission required. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/music/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=16786">MUSC 0640 S01</a></h5>

																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="MUSC0642">
					<h4>World Music Ensemble</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">This ensemble focuses on global percussive and song traditions, especially those of the African diaspora (based on instructor's vast musical experiences). Here western instrumentalists fuse with traditional musicians from every culture: bongo, gyil, ukulele, tabla, etc. Students will grow and develop their musical skills by learning new techniques on their own instrument, exploring a range of repertoire representing genres such as highlife, reggae, salsa, afrobeat, Afro-jazz, and global fusions. There will be unique opportunities to work on improvisation taking influence from Steve Reich, Tito Puente, Randy Weston, Hugh Masekela, Paul Simon, Miriam Makeba, Ghanaba, and Milton Nasimiento. DPLL </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/music/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=16787">MUSC 0642 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Obeng</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="MUSC0645">
					<h4>Brazilian Choro Ensemble</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">Half credit each semester. Students will play this popular Brazilian style, which emerged in the late 19th century and is often compared to early jazz. Classes run according to the traditional roda model, a structured jam session where performers read through, improvise upon, and hone their abilities to play familiar tunes. Prior familiarity with choro music not required, but some instrumental expertise is. Ability to read notation preferred. Typical instruments include guitar, cavaquinho (Brazilian ukulele), mandolin, flute, and pandeiro (Brazilian tambourine), but others may participate on instructor approval. Enrollment limit 20. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/music/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=16560">MUSC 0645 S01</a></h5>

					<div class="course-overview">Half credit each semester. Instruction, rehearsals, and performances in the gamelan music of Java, on instruments owned by the department. No prerequisites.  Enrollment limited to 18 students. </div>

					<h4>Chamber Music Performance</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">Half credit each semester. The practical study of the literature of chamber music through participation in a small ensemble. Regular rehearsals, coaching by department staff, and performances are required. Enrollment is by audition.  Students will be notified of audition results within the first ten days of the semester. Restricted to skilled instrumentalists.  May be repeated for credit. </div>

					<div class="course-overview">Half credit each semester. Restricted to skilled musicians. Openings are limited. Enrollment and re-enrollment is by audition and jury. Lessons are given by consultants to the Applied Music Program. A fee is charged for enrollment. Copies of the Applied Music Program Guidelines giving detailed information are available online at www.brown.edu/music.  May be repeated up to four times for credit. </div>

										<li id="MUSC0930">
					<h4>Romantic and Modern Music</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">A history of European and American art music from Beethoven to the Postmodernists. Prerequisite: MUSC 0550 or permission of instructor. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">

										<li id="MUSC1010">
					<h4>Advanced Musicianship I</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">Training in advanced musicianship skills relevant to Western art music from the sixteenth Century to the present, including sight singing, ear training, score reading, keyboard harmony, improvisation, and musical transcription. Prerequisite: MUSC 0560 with a grade of B, or permission of the instructor. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/music/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=16530">MUSC 1010 S01</a></h5>

																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="MUSC1040">
					<h4>Analysis of Romantic Musics</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">This is an analysis course focusing on music of 19th -century Western concert tradition. The primary goal is to improve and introduce new analysis skills related to chromatic harmony and form. The course proceeds by distinctive genres, including examples of solo piano works, lieder, string quartets and other chamber works, symphonies, tone poems, and opera. Though the emphasis is primarily on analyzing purely musical elements, we will also touch on broader issues of Romantic aesthetics and cultural contexts, such as fragmentation, virtuosity, nostalgia, and the debate over absolute and programmatic music. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/music/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=16537">MUSC 1040 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Wang</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="MUSC1100">
					<h4>Introduction to Composition</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">Composition students begin by using technical resources developed in their previous theoretical studies. Analysis and discussion of contemporary music provides examples of alternatives to traditional compositional strategies, which students integrate into later assignments. A study of contemporary notational practices and computer-based manuscripting and sequencing is also included. Prerequisite: MUSC 0560 or permission of the instructor.  Enrollment limited to 20 students. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/music/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=16536">MUSC 1100 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Wang</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="MUSC1210">
					<h4>Seminar in Electronic Music: Real-Time Systems</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">Seminar in Electronic Music is a study of music employing electronic media, including real-time digital signal processing, multimedia, and live performance. Technical aspects of the course focus on programming using Max/MSP to create interactive projects and algorithmic compositions. Permission of instructor required. Interested students must come to the first class.  Preference will be given to students who have completed MUSC 0200. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/music/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=16541">MUSC 1210 S01</a></h5>

										<li id="MUSC1235">
					<h4>Exploration in Video Art (VISA 1730)</h4>
					<div class="course-overview"> </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/music/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=17679">MUSC 1235 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="MUSC1240I">
					<h4>Building Musical Instruments</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">In Building Musical Instruments, we will study and create expressive musical sound by building acoustic, analog, and digital instruments. Using sonic goals as inspiration for design features, we will build handheld acoustic instruments, contact microphones, basic synthesizers, and digital controllers, and we will consider the ways in which these distinct objects can work together to form a musical performance system. Topics include: musical listening and design, resonance of different materials, soldering, breadboarding, reading a basic schematic diagram, creating an enclosure, and expressive interaction with instruments. No prerequisites. Maximum enrollment: 12. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/music/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=17573">MUSC 1240I S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Warren</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="MUSC1240L">
					<h4>Rhythm Beyond Music</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">This course foregrounds the concept of rhythm as it appears across disciplines from philosophy to ecology to neuroscience to media theory. We will explore what rhythm means in these contexts and how it relates to aesthetic practices in the sonic, visual, and digital arts. We will ask what are the ontologies, practices, and politics of non-object and processual-based means of being in the world. The course takes a hybrid theory/practice approach. Classes consist of reading and discussion of texts and exemplary artworks in seminar format. Students will produce projects that build toward “artistic research” in any medium for in-class critique. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/music/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=17495">MUSC 1240L S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>House</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="MUSC1250">
					<h4>Sound Design</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">This production seminar is a study of techniques and aesthetics used to create sonic environments and effects that enhance a variety of media including video, radio and audio art, new media, theater, and installation art. Technical topics include audio production in multi-channel formats, advanced audio editing, mixing and synthesis techniques, and audio system design. Enrollment limited to 12 students. Preference will be given to students who have completed MUSC 1200. Others will be evaluated for potential future work in the MEME program (Multimedia and Electronic Music Experiments) and past participation in MEME. Admission is determined by an entrance questionnaire completed at the first class meeting. Prereq: MUSC 1200. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/music/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=16538">MUSC 1250 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Moses</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="MUSC1400">
					<h4>Music, Civil Society, and Public Service</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">The course will explore questions of an artist's role in the world, and will include an inquiry into a set of ideas in philosophy of aesthetics; an inquiry into activism and developing social practice as artists; discussion on philosophy of education as it relates to the question of positive social change; and an exploration of musical and artistic initiatives that have been particularly focused on a positive social impact. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/music/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=17595">MUSC 1400 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Ruth</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="MUSC1500A">
					<h4>Major Masters and Repertoires of Music: Bach</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">An examination of the life and work of Bach, including its placce in German church music, views of his contemporaries and explanation of hi manuscript and publishing history. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/music/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=16532">MUSC 1500A S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Jodry</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="MUSC1701">
					<h4>Orchestral Conducting</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">We will discuss, study and practice various technical approaches to conducting through the examination of standard repertoire. Students will develop skills in score reading and analysis. This course will provide a supportive workshop environment. Students will be given the opportunity to conduct an in class ensemble. Repertoire will small to large symphonic works from Händel through Stravinsky, depending upon the needs of each student and over all class level. 

Pre-Requisites: MUSC 0550-0560. Audition on the first day of class with Händel’s Messiah Overture. Students will play for their colleagues. Prior knowledge of orchestration and instrumentation is helpful. Knowledge of transposition and C clefs is helpful. If you have placed out of music theory at Brown or have questions, please contact the instructor at: brandon_brown@brown.edu

 </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/music/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=17569">MUSC 1701 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Brown</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="MUSC1810">
					<h4>Applied Music Program: Instruction in Vocal or Instrumental Music - Voice</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">Half credit each semester. Restricted to skilled musicians. Restricted to skilled musicians demonstrating mastery of an advanced repertory in their fields.  Openings are limited. Enrollment and re-enrollment is by audition and jury. Lessons are given by consultants to the Applied Music Program.  MUSC 0830, 0840 is prerequisite to this course.  A fee is charged for enrollment.  Copies of the Applied Music Program Guidelines giving detailed information are available online at www.brown.edu/music.  Prerequisite: MUSC 0400, or MUSC 0550, MUSC 0560.  Written permission required.   May be repeated up to four times for credit. </div>

				</li>
										<li id="MUSC1900">
					<h4>Introduction to Ethnomusicology</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">This seminar offers an introduction to theory and method in ethnomusicology, a discipline grounded in ethnographic research and writing on musical practices. We will think, talk, and write about how and why people make music, as well as how and why ethnomusicologists go about their work. Students will undertake independent fieldwork projects, learning first-hand about both the special potential and the practical/ethical challenges of this type of research. Case studies highlight such issues as tradition, appropriation, postcolonial politics, and the ethics of fieldwork. Prerequisites: sophomore standing; MUSC 0550 or instructor permission. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/music/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=16534">MUSC 1900 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Miller</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="MUSC1923">
					<h4>Music in the Andean Countries: From Cumbia to Carnavalito</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">This course provides an introduction to the music of South America’s Andean countries. Through texts, listenings, and hands-on instruction, students will explore the social histories and stylistic principles of genres like Colombian and Peruvian cumbia, Afro-Peruvian festejo and landó, Chilean nueva canción, and the sikuri and huayno music of South Andean Quechua and Aymara peoples. Class sessions balance cultural analysis with opportunities to play, and students are expected to develop some facility with key songs and rhythms. No experience is necessary, though inexperienced musicians can expect to focus on instrumental or vocal parts that present a lower bar to participation. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/music/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=17105">MUSC 1923 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Tucker</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="MUSC1960">
					<h4>Advanced Ghanaian Drumming and Dancing Ensemble</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">Students with experience in African and related musical traditions perform drumming, dancing, and singing of Ghana and the diaspora.  Focus on a more challenging repertoire with emphasis on multi-part, lead, and improvisational playing. Prerequisite:  audition. May be repeatable for credit.  Instructor permission required.  Enrollment limited to 15 students. </div>

							<h5><a href="/academics/music/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=13829">MUSC 1970 S22</a></h5>
														<dl>

															</dl>

												</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="MUSC2070">
					<h4>Music and Identity</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">From 19th-century European nationalism to 20th-century American multiculturalism, people have used music to affirm their identities. Drawing on anthropological and sociological theory, we examine the variety of connections between music and identity in several case studies. We consider the possible contributions of music to cross- cultural understanding, and discuss the ethics of musical border- crossing. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/music/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=16543">MUSC 2070 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Perlman</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="MUSC2080B">
					<h4>Ethnography of Popular Music</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">This seminar explores ethnographic work on popular music, including scholarship rooted in ethnomusicology, sociology, and performance studies. We will discuss case studies from around the world and will compare contemporary ethnographic research with other approaches to popular music (e.g., Frankfurt School critical theory, Birmingham School cultural studies, and text-oriented popular music studies). Prerequisite: graduate standing or written permission. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/music/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=16555">MUSC 2080B S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Miller</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="MUSC2080H">
					<h4>Key Concepts in Sociocultural Theory</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">Ethnomusicology has always been interdisciplinary, and is becoming more so.  The student today may encounter concepts from semiotics, linguistics, cultural studies, literary theory, political economy, sociology, cognitive psychology, media studies, sound studies, science and technology studies, organizational studies, and material culture studies, and other disciplines as well.  We will examine some of the key concepts of these fields and consider their possible uses in the study of the performing arts.  From ‘affordances’ to the ‘type/token distinction,’ from ‘actor-network theory’ to the ‘third-person effect,’ we will learn to apply (and criticize) concepts presupposed by much current socio-cultural theorizing. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/music/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=17305">MUSC 2080H S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Perlman</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="MUSC2210">
					<h4>Digital Performance</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">A production seminar examining the artistic impact and creative potential of digital media in the context of live performance. Readings and analysis of work examine innovations in performance practice from dance, theatre, performance art and music. Collaborative assignments investigate video projection, sound design and interactive sensor technology, culminating in a final large-scale performance. Permission will be granted based upon a questionnaire given in the first class. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/music/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=16558">MUSC 2210 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Winkler</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="MUSC2235">
					<h4>Timbre in Electroacoustic Music</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">We will investiage the topic of timbre in electroacoustic music though both analysis and composition. We will study musical compositions in various media (acoustic and electronic) that use timbre in various ways, scholarly writing that looks in more depth at compositional processes involving timbre (such as in Spectral music), and various software programs that can assist in analysis and composition. Students will compose new works for electronics alone, as well as for guest solo performers with interactive electronics to be performed in a public concert. Enrollment limited to 8. Permission required for undergraduates. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/music/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=17146">MUSC 2235 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Nathan</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="MUSC2245">
					<h4>Experimental Voice</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">In Experimental Voice, we will study and undertake acoustic and electronic modifications of voice. We will consider applications of voice by diverse practitioners such as Jaap Blonk, Ami Yoshida, and Pamela Z. Using these pieces as inspiration, we will make creative and critical work aimed at challenging and broadening our notions of what voice and vocal performance can be. Students from all departments are welcome. Prerequisites: none. Permission required for undergraduates. Maximum enrollment: 12. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/music/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=17617">MUSC 2245 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Warren</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="MUSC2300A">
					<h4>Critical Improvisation Studies</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">Advanced seminar exploring improvisation from various perspectives: historical, anthropological, philosophical, ethical, and creative. We study improvisation in diverse musical traditions, in other arts, and in problem-solving contexts such as business, technology, and games. Discussion topics include individual vs. group improvisation, the status of "freedom" in creative processes, and the social and artistic functions of improvisation. Instructor permission required. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/music/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=16549">MUSC 2300A S01</a></h5>
														<dl>

<script type="text/javascript">
	// @todo: make show/hide link dynamically generated
	$(document).ready(function(){
	
		$(".course-list .additional-sections").hide();

		// add additional sections toggle link
		$(".course-list .additional-sections").each(function(i,el){
			var numSections = $(".section", $(this)).length;
			numSections = (numSections == 1) ? numSections + " additional section" : numSections + " additional sections";
			var anchor = $(this).parents("li").attr('id');
			$(this).after('<span class="section-count">[<a href="#' + anchor + '">Show ' + numSections + '</a>]</span>');
		});

		// now add the show/hide event listeners		
		$(".section-count").each(function(i,el){
			$("a", this).bind("click keypress", function(){
				$(".additional-sections", $(this).parents("li")).slideToggle("fast");
				window.location.hash = $(this).attr("href");
				if($(this).html().match(/Show/)) {
					$(this).html($(this).html().replace("Show", "Hide"));
				} else if($(this).html().match(/Hide/)) {
					$(this).html($(this).html().replace("Hide", "Show"));
				}
				this.text(($('#toggle').text() == 'Show more') ? 'Show less' : 'Show more');
				return false;
			});
		});
		
		if (window.location.hash) {
			var hash = window.location.hash;
			if(hash.match(/#[0-9]{4}/)) {
				$(hash +  " .additional-sections").slideDown("fast");
				$(hash +  " a[href='"+hash+"']").html($(hash +  " a[href='"+hash+"']").html().replace("Show", "Hide"));
			}
		}

	});
</script>
							</div>

		<section id="content-bottom">
			
<div id="spotlight" class="clear-block block block-views the-bar">

  <h2>Spotlight</h2>
  <div class="content"><div class="view view-thebar view-id-thebar view-display-id-block_1 view-dom-id-3">
    
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
      <ul class="jcarousel jcarousel-view--thebar--block-1 jcarousel-dom-1 jcarousel-skin-default">
      <li class="jcarousel-item-1 odd">  
  <div class="views-field-field-bar-image-fid">
                <span class="field-content"><a href="http://www.browndailyherald.com/2017/10/03/lumen-gallery-provide-new-meditative-space-granoff/"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/music/sites/brown.edu.academics.music/files/imagecache/bar_item_image/bar-items/images/granoff-650x397.jpg" alt="" title="" width="160" height="90" class="imagecache imagecache-bar_item_image imagecache-default imagecache-bar_item_image_default"/></a></span>

  </div>

  </div>

  </ul>
    </div>

		<img  class="imagefield imagefield-field_ultibanner_image" width="940" height="200" alt="" src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/music/sites/brown.edu.academics.music/files/ultibanner/Graduate-Header-940x200.jpg?1504290199" />	<!--/div-->

<!-- Layout -->

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Graduate</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
<article id="node-13" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <h2><span>Graduate Programs in Music</span></h2>
<p><em>Please note: the graduate program in Ethnomusicology will not be accepting any applications for the 2018-19 academic year.</em></p>
<p>The Department of Music currently offers the Ph.D. in Music in two areas of study: Ethnomusicology and Computer Music (otherwise known as MEME: Multimedia and Electronic Music Experiments). The long-standing doctoral program in Ethnomusicology, established in 1968, is one of the first in the country, while the MEME doctoral program became a fully-fledged Ph.D. in 2004. The small size of both allows for significant cross talk between the students.<br /><br />Such dialogues tend to reach beyond the department as well. Brown graduate students regularly explore offerings in many other disciplines as part of their courses of study. Students in ethnomusicology are to be found just as often in the music building as they are in anthropology, psychology, American Studies, Africana studies and Portuguese and Brazilian studies. In the same way, students in Computer Music and Multimedia make connections with faculty in Modern Culture and Media, Visual Art, Literary Arts and Engineering. At Brown, your degree is what you make it: the more adventurous you are, the more exciting your program is likely to be.</p>
<h3>For more information</h3>
<p>Please see the <a href="node/230" rel="nofollow">Ethnomusicology</a> and <a href="node/272" rel="nofollow">MEME</a> pages for detailed information on each program. Also, visit&nbsp;the <a href="http://www.brown.edu/gradschool" title="Brown Graduate School Home Page">Graduate School</a> and the <a href="http://www.brown.edu/about/administration/financial-aid/graduate/overview" title="Graduate Section of the Office of Financial Aid website">Office of Financial Aid</a>&nbsp;sites as well.</p>
  </div>

	
  <div class="clear-block">
    <div class="meta">

			
	    
		</div><!-- end .meta -->
	</div>

</article>
							</div>

							
													</div><!-- end .second-column -->
						
													<div id="sidebar-left" class="sidebar first-column column">
								
	
	<div id="block-menu-primary-links" class="clear-block block block-menu ">
	
		
		<div class="content"><ul class="menu"><li class="leaf first menu-home"><a href="/academics/music/news" title="Home">Home</a></li>
<li class="collapsed menu-about"><a href="/academics/music/about" title="">About</a></li>
<li class="collapsed menu-people"><a href="/academics/music/people" title="People">People</a></li>
<li class="collapsed menu-undergraduate"><a href="/academics/music/undergraduate" title="Undergraduate">Undergraduate</a></li>
<li class="expanded active-trail menu-graduate"><a href="/academics/music/graduate" title="Graduate" class="active">Graduate</a><ul class="menu"><li class="collapsed first menu-computermusicmeme"><a href="/academics/music/computer-music-multimedia-meme" title="">Computer Music (MEME)</a></li>

</ul></li>

</ul></div>
			
				
	</div>


	
	<div id="block-brown_social_media-0" class="clear-block block block-brown_social_media ">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Graduate Students</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
<article id="node-225" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <p><a href="#memegrads" rel="nofollow">Computer Music and Multimedia</a>&nbsp; |&nbsp; <a href="#ethnograds" rel="nofollow">Ethnomusicology</a></p>
<h3><a name="memegrads"></a>Computer Music and Multimedia</h3>
<table>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>
<p><strong><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:108px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/music/sites/brown.edu.academics.music/files/images/NicoleCarroll.thumbnail.jpg" alt="Nicole Carroll" title="Nicole Carroll"  class="image image-thumbnail " width="100" height="100" /><span class="caption"><strong>Nicole Carroll</strong></span></span></strong><strong>Nicole Carroll</strong><br />Nicole Carroll is a composer, performer, sound designer, and builder currently based in Brisbane, Australia, where she is an Adjunct Research Fellow at QCGU. Her work spans installation, improvisation, and fixed media performance. She performs electronic music under the alias “n0izmkr.” Themes in her work derive from reflections on nature, occult philosophies, literature, and the human psyche. <a href="http://www.nicolecarrollmusic.com" rel="nofollow">www.nicolecarrollmusic.com</a></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>
<p><strong><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:108px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/music/sites/brown.edu.academics.music/files/images/Alex Dupuis.jpg" alt="Alexander Dupuis" title="Alexander Dupuis"  class="image image-_original " width="100" height="100" /><span class="caption"><strong>Alexander Dupuis</strong></span></span>Alexander Dupuis<br /></strong>Alexander Dupuis is a video artist, composer, and performer based in  Providence, RI.&nbsp; Current areas of focus include designing generative  audiovisual systems and performing real-time animations in musical  contexts. He is active as a guitarist in the Happy Valley Band and the  Verdant Vibes new music collective. <a href="http://www.alexanderdupuis.com" title="www.alexanderdupuis.com">www.alexanderdupuis.com</a></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>
<p><strong><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:108px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/music/sites/brown.edu.academics.music/files/images/Martim-Galvao_0.jpg" alt="Martim Galvao" title="Martim Galvao"  class="image image-_original " width="100" height="100" /><span class="caption"><strong>Martim Galvao</strong></span></span>Martim Schneider Galvão</strong><br />Martim S. Galvão is a composer, percussionist and intermedia artist. Much of his work is concerned with patterns, cycles and repetition. He is especially interested in exploring ideas related to consumerism and internet culture. Galvão earned his bachelor’s degree from Emory University. In 2014 he graduated from the Integrated Composition, Improvisation, and Technology (ICIT) MFA program at the UC Irvine. <a href="http://www.martim.xyz" rel="nofollow">www.martim.xyz</a></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>
<p><strong><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:108px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/music/sites/brown.edu.academics.music/files/images/house.thumbnail.jpg" alt="Brian House" title="Brian House"  class="image image-thumbnail " width="100" height="100" /><span class="caption"><strong>Brian House</strong></span></span>Brian House</strong><em>&nbsp;</em><br />Brian House is an artist who works with the material ecologies of sound and data. By constructing embodied, participatory systems, he explores how&nbsp;computational temporalities negotiate with the rhythms of everyday life. His work has been shown by MoMA in New York, MOCA in Los Angeles, Ars&nbsp;Electronica, Cincinnati Contemporary Arts Center, Eyebeam, Rhizome, Los Angeles Contemporary Exhibitions, Conflux Festival, ISEA, NIME, and&nbsp;Issue Project Room, among others, and has been featured in publications including WIRED, TIME, The New York Times, SPIN, Metropolis, and on&nbsp;Univision Sports. He holds a degree in computer science from Columbia University and one in art from Chalmers University (Sweden). In addition to his doctoral work&nbsp;at MEME, Brian completed a masters in Modern Culture and Media at Brown. <a href="https://brianhouse.net/" rel="nofollow">http://brianhouse.net</a></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>
<p><strong><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:108px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/music/sites/brown.edu.academics.music/files/images/Kim3.thumbnail.jpg" alt="Jinku Kim" title="Jinku Kim"  class="image image-thumbnail " width="100" height="100" /><span class="caption"><strong>Jinku Kim</strong></span></span>Jinku Kim</strong><strong>&nbsp;</strong><em>&nbsp;</em><br />Jinku is a composer, performer, and multimedia artist currently  residing in New England Area. His work focuses on pushing the boundaries  of interaction through sound installation and audio visual  performances. His works have been performed and installed at various  places including REDCAT of Walt Disney Concert Hall, CEMEC in Stanford  University, UC San Diego, UC Santa Barbara and Mills College, STEIM in  Amsterdam, Beyond Baroque in Venice CA, Machine project in Los Angeles.<a href="http://www.grayscale64.com" rel="nofollow">www.grayscale64.com</a></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>
<p><strong><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:108px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/music/sites/brown.edu.academics.music/files/images/Luke Moldof MEME Photo Sol.thumbnail.jpeg" alt="Luke Moldof" title="Luke Moldof"  class="image image-thumbnail " width="100" height="100" /><span class="caption"><strong>Luke Moldof</strong></span></span>Luke </strong><strong>Moldof<em>&nbsp;</em></strong> <br />Luke Moldof is an  electronic musician based out of Providence, Rhode Island. He received a  BM from the New England Conservatory of Music. His current work  utilizes flexible real-time modular electronic systems that split the  difference between composition and improvisation through complex  feedback loops and varying degrees of controlled randomness. Often these  systems are made to respond to or coincide with the outside influence  of reel to reel tape loops, field recordings, and prepared guitar  improvisations. Moldof has performed at venues including Issue Project  Room, The Stone, and lots of people’s basements.</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>
<p><strong><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:108px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/music/sites/brown.edu.academics.music/files/images/Marcel-Sagesser_0.jpg" alt="Marcel Sagesser" title="Marcel Sagesser"  class="image image-_original " width="100" height="100" /><span class="caption"><strong>Marcel Sagesser</strong></span></span>Marcel Sagesser</strong><strong>&nbsp;</strong><em>&nbsp;</em><span class="il">&nbsp;</span><span class="il"><br /></span><span>Marcel Sagesser, born in Berne, Switzerland, is an artist and performer-composer under the stage name ‘Marcel Zaes.’ He holds an M.A. in Music &amp; Media Arts from Berne University of the Arts, an M.A. in Music Composition from Zurich University of the Arts and has additionally completed private composition studies with Alvin Curran in Rome and with Peter Ablinger in Berlin. <a href="http://www.marcelzaes.com/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">www.marcelzaes.com</a></span></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>
<p><strong><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:108px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/music/sites/brown.edu.academics.music/files/images/Asha.thumbnail.JPG" alt="Asha Tamirisa" title="Asha Tamirisa"  class="image image-thumbnail " width="100" height="100" /><span class="caption"><strong>Asha Tamirisa</strong></span></span>Asha Tamirisa</strong><strong>&nbsp;</strong><em>&nbsp;</em><em>&nbsp;</em><br />Asha Tamirisa is often found working with some combination of sound, video, sculpture, and movement. She graduated from Oberlin College with a degree in Technology in Music and Related Arts [TIMARA] and is currently a doctoral student in the Multimedia and Electronic Music Experiments [MEME] program at Brown University. She is also concurrently working towards an MA in Modern Culture and Media [MCM] at Brown. Current research interests include gender, race and technology, interfaces and tool-making, and audiovisual synthesis and video art. She is a founding member of OPENSIGNAL, a group of artists concerned with the state of gender and race within electronic / computer based art practices.&nbsp;<a href="http://www.ashatamirisa.net" rel="nofollow">www.ashatamirisa.net&nbsp;</a></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>
<p><strong><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:108px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/music/sites/brown.edu.academics.music/files/images/Seth-Thorn_0.jpg" alt="Seth Thorn" title="Seth Thorn"  class="image image-_original " width="100" height="100" /><span class="caption"><strong>Seth Thorn</strong></span></span>Seth Thorn</strong><br />Seth is a composer-performer, violist, hardware designer, and interdisciplinary scholar whose work examines the relationship between gesture and sound. His research integrates texts on classical aesthetics, phenomenology, spectacle, interactivity, embodied cognition, and the sociology of craftsmanship. Seth has graduate degrees in German studies, political theory, and computer music. His compositions have been invited for performance at ICMC, NIME, and NYCEMF.&nbsp; <a href="http://www.seththorn.net" rel="nofollow">www.seththorn.net</a></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>
<p><strong>Amber Vistein</strong><br />Amber is a composer and sound artist whose work frequently takes the form of immersive multimedia installation and electronically mediated live performance. She capitalizes on sound’s ability to transport the listener to a fictional space. In order to articulate the enfolded complexity of a sonic world, she simultaneously incorporates elements of field recording, narrative, theatre, and music. Amber Vistein received her MFA in 2013 from the Studio for Interrelated Media at Massachusetts College of Art and Design.</p>
</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<h3><a name="ethnograds"></a>Ethnomusicology</h3>
<hr />
<hr />
<table>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>
<p><strong><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:108px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/music/sites/brown.edu.academics.music/files/images/Luis-Achondo.jpg" alt="Luis Achondo" title="Luis Achondo"  class="image image-_original " width="100" height="100" /><span class="caption"><strong>Luis Achondo</strong></span></span>Luis Achondo<em><br /></em></strong>Luis is a Ph.D. student and Fulbright scholar from Chile. He holds a B.A. and an M.A. in Music from the Pontificia Universidad Católica and an M.A. in Ethnomusicology from Brown. His doctoral project examines how Argentine soccer supporters produce and comprehend sound, exploring issues such as violence, affect, place, the sensorium, and how sound inhabits the country’s public sphere.</p>
<p><span> </span></p></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>
<p><strong><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:108px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/music/sites/brown.edu.academics.music/files/images/Cavicchi.thumbnail.JPG" alt="Violet Cavicchi" title="Violet Cavicchi"  class="image image-thumbnail " width="100" height="100" /><span class="caption"><strong>Violet Cavicchi</strong></span></span>Violet Cavicchi</strong><em><br /></em><span>Violet is a doctoral student at Brown. Her dissertation project investigates the workings of Andean music technoculture that links past and present, urban and rural, and people of varied ethnic, racial, and class positions. She focuses on personalized and communal uses of music in radio broadcasting, music video production, and home recordings of live performances of the bandurria, a string instrument from Cusco. She received her B.A. at Vassar College in Anthropology with a correlate in Music and Culture and wrote her senior thesis on mixing music as a means of cultural intermediation for Latin DJs in NYC. <br /></span></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>
<p><strong><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:108px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/music/sites/brown.edu.academics.music/files/images/Melody-Chapin.jpg" alt="Melody Chapin" title="Melody Chapin"  class="image image-_original " width="100" height="100" /><span class="caption"><strong>Melody Chapin</strong></span></span>Melody Chapin</strong><em>&nbsp;</em><br />Melody studies Brazilian opera and art music from the early to mid twentieth&nbsp;century. Her broader interests include Western-styled art music in postcolonial countries. Melody’s second project regards loud music listening practices among underrepresented populations in the United States. She has a BM in Voice Performance (University of New Hampshire) and an MA in Musicology (Tufts University).</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>
<p><strong><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:108px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/music/sites/brown.edu.academics.music/files/images/Jamie-Corbett.jpg" alt="Jamie Corbett" title="Jamie Corbett"  class="image image-_original " width="100" height="100" /><span class="caption"><strong>Jamie Corbett</strong></span></span>Jamie Corbett</strong> <br /><em><span> </span></em><span>Jamie is a fourth-year PhD student. Coming to Brown after completing a B.Mus at the University of Toronto, she is currently conducting fieldwork in Florianopolis, an island city in the south of Brazil. Her dissertation project explores the institutional, historical, and political life of contemporary folklore performance, including the theatrical tradition boi-de-mamão, the song genre of ratoeira, and various dances of Azorean origin.</span></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>
<p><strong><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:108px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/music/sites/brown.edu.academics.music/files/images/katie freeze_0.thumbnail.jpg" alt="Katie Freeze" title="Katie Freeze"  class="image image-thumbnail " width="100" height="100" /><span class="caption"><strong>Katie Freeze</strong></span></span>Katie Freeze<em>&nbsp;</em></strong><br /><span>Katie studies the diverse music cultures of the mountainous “roof of the world” of South and Central Asia. She plays the Western Tibetan ko-phongs and the Pamiri rubob and tanbur, and her doctoral project explores contemporary musical performance and representation among Ismaili Muslims living in post-Soviet, Tajik Badakhshan. Katie holds music degrees from the University of Washington and, before coming to Brown, worked as a pianist, composer and arranger.</span></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>
<p><strong><strong><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:108px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/music/sites/brown.edu.academics.music/files/images/KateHaughey.thumbnail.jpg" alt="Kate Haughey" title="Kate Haughey"  class="image image-thumbnail " width="100" height="100" /><span class="caption"><strong>Kate Haughey</strong></span></span>Kathleen Haughey</strong></strong><em><br /></em>Kathleen (Kate) Haughey is the Executive Director at the Vermont Folklife Center, and a PhD candidate in ethnomusicology. For her MA, Kathleen co-led an audio documentary project with Mbyá-Guarani musicians in southern Brazil. This project focused on the importance of negotiation and collaboration in small, community-led ethnographic projects. Kate’s dissertation explores the roles of music and dance in the Bhutanese Nepali refugee communities in Vermont.&nbsp; <a href="http://www.vermontfolklifecenter.org" rel="nofollow">www.vermontfolklifecenter.org</a></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>
<p><strong><strong><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:108px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/music/sites/brown.edu.academics.music/files/images/cora.thumbnail.jpg" alt="Cora Johnson-Roberson" title="Cora Johnson-Roberson"  class="image image-thumbnail " width="100" height="100" /><span class="caption"><strong>Cora Johnson-Roberson</strong></span></span>Cora Johnson-Roberson</strong></strong><em></em><em></em><br /><span>Cora is a Ph.D candidate in ethnomusicology. They received their B.A. in History and Literature &amp; Music from Harvard College, where they wrote a senior thesis on the political ramifications of Zulu women's music. Their research interests include black music from across the African Diaspora, queerness, and virtual communities. Their dissertation project explores the embodied practice and social mediation of ballroom/vogue, a Black and Latinx LGBTQ musical genre and dance practice with roots in 1960s Harlem.</span></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>
<p><strong><strong><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:108px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/music/sites/brown.edu.academics.music/files/images/Esther1.thumbnail.jpg" alt="Esther Kurtz" title="Esther Kurtz"  class="image image-thumbnail " width="100" height="100" /><span class="caption"><strong>Esther Kurtz</strong></span></span>Esther Viola Kurtz</strong></strong><em></em><em><br /></em>Esther is a PhD candidate in Ethnomusicology with a B.M. from Eastman School of Music and an M.M. from Utrecht Conservatory in oboe performance. Her dissertation&nbsp; explores how practitioners of capoeira Angola, an Afro-Brazilian music-movement form, interpret and shift their understandings of race, self and community in Brazil. She trains capoeira, plays music and dances every chance she gets.</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>
<p><strong><strong><strong><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:108px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/music/sites/brown.edu.academics.music/files/images/12901520_988638617858644_7771712283614551014_o (2) (1).thumbnail.jpg" alt="Byrd McDaniel" title="Byrd McDaniel"  class="image image-thumbnail " width="100" height="100" /><span class="caption"><strong>Byrd McDaniel</strong></span></span>Byrd McDaniel</strong></strong></strong><em><br /> </em>A Ph.D. candidate in ethnomusicology, Byrd researches popular music reception in the U.S., emphasizing listening, disability, and amateur performance. His dissertation features case studies on karaoke, air guitar competitions, and lip syncing. Byrd received an M.A. in American studies at the University of Alabama, and he designed and taught courses at University of Alabama, Brown University, and Tufts University. <a href="http://byrdmcdaniel.com" title="http://byrdmcdaniel.com">http://byrdmcdaniel.com</a></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>
<p><strong><strong><strong><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:108px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/music/sites/brown.edu.academics.music/files/images/Portrait 2.thumbnail.jpg" alt="Louis-Emmanuel Wenger" title="Louis-Emmanuel Wenger"  class="image image-thumbnail " width="100" height="100" /><span class="caption"><strong>Louis-Emmanuel Wenger</strong></span></span>Louis-Emmanuel Wenger</strong></strong></strong><br />Louis, who is a PhD candidate in ethnomusicology, holds a B.A. in Music Studies and an M.A. in Ethnomusicology from the School of Oriental and African Studies (SOAS), University of London. Louis specializes in the musics of Centra Asia and the Middle East, with a strong emphasis on Iran and the wider Persian speaking world. Additionally, his interest extends to West Africa and the Maghreb. His current research interests include the role of Jewish performers in the development of urban music in Muslim societies, the impact of cultural policies and NGOs on local music practices, the relationship between music, politics, and religion; and the links between music and identity in diaspora communities.</p>
</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<div class="image-clear"></div>  </div>

	
  <div class="clear-block">
    <div class="meta">

			
	    
		</div><!-- end .meta -->
	</div>

</article>
							</div>

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">404: Not Found</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column no-left-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
<article id="node-172" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <p>The page that you requested could not be found.</p>
<p>Consider trying the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.brown.edu/search/google/">search</a>, the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.brown.edu/a-to-z">A-Z directory</a>, or one of the Audience Gateways located at the top of the page.</p>
  </div>

	
  <div class="clear-block">
    <div class="meta">

			
	    
		</div><!-- end .meta -->
	</div>

</article>

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Computer Music &amp; Multimedia (MEME)</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
<article id="node-272" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <p id="docs-internal-guid-425ab877-f092-53ee-20d3-79413612a3c4"><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:518px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/music/sites/brown.edu.academics.music/files/images/PB-vidStripes-small2.brown_slides_main_column.jpg" alt="" title=""  class="image image-brown_slides_main_column " width="510" height="287" /></span></p>
<p>MEME (Multimedia &amp; Electronic Music Experiments) is an interdisciplinary program within the Brown University Music Department that focuses on the creative use of emerging technology for real-time interactive performance and installation. meme@brown is known for art and research that traverse the boundaries between computer music, installation, video, theater and dance.</p>
<p>As part of the larger Brown and RISD digital media community, meme@brown provides expertise and promotes research in real-time electronic music, instrument design, interactive video, motion tracking and other hardware/software. Local, national and international artists are featured regularly at MEME concerts, symposia, and workshops.</p>
<h5></h5>
<h5></h5>
<h5></h5>
<h5></h5>
<h5></h5>
<h5></h5>
<h5></h5>
<h5></h5>
<h5></h5>
<h5></h5>
<h5></h5>
<h5></h5>
<h5></h5>
<h5>Faculty</h5>
<p><a href="https://vivo.brown.edu/display/jrovan">Joseph Butch Rovan</a>, Co-Director&nbsp;<br /><a href="http://www.soundidea.org/" rel="nofollow">Website</a>&nbsp;|&nbsp;<a href="mailto:rovan@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">rovan@brown.edu</a></p>
<p><a href="https://vivo.brown.edu/display/twinkler">Todd Winkler</a>, Co-Director<br /><a href="http://www.brown.edu/Departments/Music/sites/winkler/">Website</a>&nbsp;|&nbsp;<a href="mailto:Todd_Winkler@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">Todd_Winkler@brown.edu</a></p>
<p><a href="https://vivo.brown.edu/display/jmoses">James Moses</a>, Technical Director/Lecturer<br /><a href="http://jimmoses.wordpress.com/" rel="nofollow">Website</a>&nbsp;|&nbsp;<a href="mailto:jmoses@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">jmoses@brown.edu</a></p>
<p><a href="https://vivo.brown.edu/display/kwarren1">Kristina Warren</a>,&nbsp;<span>Visiting Assistant Professor<br /><a href="http://kmwarren.org/" rel="nofollow">Website</a><span>&nbsp;|&nbsp;</span><span><a href="mailto:kristina_warren@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">kristina_warren@brown.edu</a></span></span></p>
<h5>Associated Faculty</h5>
<p><a href="https://vivo.brown.edu/display/eosborn">Ed Osborn</a>, Assistant Profesor of Visual Art<br /><a href="http://www.roving.net/" rel="nofollow">Website</a>&nbsp;|&nbsp;<a href="mailto:Ed_Osborn@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">Ed_Osborn@brown.edu</a></p>
<h5>Students</h5>
<p><a href="http://brown.edu/academics/music/about/people/graduate-students#meme-grads">Graduate Students</a><br /> <a href="http://brown.edu/academics/music/about/people/concentrators">Undergraduate Music Concentrators</a></p>
<p><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:518px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/music/sites/brown.edu.academics.music/files/images/JF-hand-wires-small.brown_slides_main_column.jpg" alt="" title=""  class="image image-brown_slides_main_column " width="510" height="287" /></span></p>
<h2>Degrees and Courses</h2>
<p>meme@brown offers an undergraduate concentration in computer music and multimedia and a Ph.D. degree in Computer Music and Multimedia. The program regularly collaborates with departments and students from across the Brown and RISD campuses and graduate and undergraduate students from a variety of disciplines participate in meme courses and research.</p>
<p><a href="http://www.brown.edu/academics/gradschool/programs/music-computer-music-and-multimedia">Graduate program information and requirements</a><br /> <a href="http://brown.edu/academics/music/undergraduate">Undergraduate information and requirements</a><br /> <a href="http://brown.edu/academics/music/courses">Music Department Courses</a><br /> <a href="http://brown.edu/academics/music/ensembles-and-lessons/electroacoustic-improv-ensemble">MEME Ensemble</a></p>
<p><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:518px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/music/sites/brown.edu.academics.music/files/images/verbosClose.ursa-feature-image.jpg" alt="" title=""  class="image image-ursa-feature-image " width="510" height="224" /></span></p>
<h2>Resources and Facilities</h2>
<ul>
<li><a href="/academics/music/meme-studios-steinert" title="MEME Studios at Steinert" rel="nofollow">Studios at the Steinert Practice Center</a></li>
<li><a href="https://sites.google.com/a/brown.edu/meme-studio-help/">Meme Studio Help</a></li>
<li><a href="https://sites.google.com/a/brown.edu/meme-studio-help/home/steinert-studio-access-policy">Studio Policies</a></li>
<li><a href="/academics/music/music-performance-spaces" title="Music Performance Spaces" rel="nofollow">Performance Spaces</a></li>
<li><a href="https://listserv.brown.edu/?SUBED1=411&amp;X=BC7273572A673DFB55&amp;Y=james_moses%40brown.edu">MEME 411 info list</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.brown.edu/information-technology/services/multimedia-labs">Brown Multimedia labs</a></li>
<li><a href="http://library.brown.edu/about/orwig/">Orwig Music Library</a></li>
<li><a href="https://brown.edu/academics/creative-arts-council/">Creative Arts Council</a></li>
<li><a href="https://brown.edu/academics/creative-arts-council/granoff">Granoff Center</a></li>
<li>Community resources
<ul>
<li><a href="http://www.as220.org/" rel="nofollow">AS220</a></li>
<li><a href="http://machineswithmagnets.com/" rel="nofollow">Machines With Magnets</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.arts.ri.gov/" rel="nofollow">Rhode island Council for the Arts</a></li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>

	<div class="tel"><span class="type">Fax</span> <span class="value">401-863-1256</span></div>
	<div><a class="email" href="mailto:music@brown.edu">music@brown.edu</a></div>
</div>
  </div>
    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div> </div>
			
				
	</div>

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Ethnomusicology</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
<article id="node-230" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <h3>Program Overview</h3>
<div id="about_text">
<p>If music affects you deeply, and if you are curious about music as a human activity, consider graduate work in ethnomusicology, the study of people making music. At Brown, students are free to explore the meanings of music and sound through broad and deep acquaintance with musical cultures throughout the world. Ethnomusicologists document, analyze, and interpret music both as design or structure, and as performance situated in its historical, aesthetic, and social contexts.</p>
<p><a href="#undergraduatelevel" rel="nofollow">Undergraduate</a> | <a href="#graduatelevel" rel="nofollow">Graduate</a> | <a href="#ethnofaculty" rel="nofollow">People</a></p>
<h6><a name="undergraduatelevel"></a>Undergraduate level</h6>
<p id="about_text">Undergraduates may pursue Ethnomusicology coursework from the moment they arrive as freshmen by enrolling in one of our first-year seminars or taking one of several introductory courses, such as<em> Latino Diaspora Music, Popular Music and Society in Latin America, World Music Cultures</em> or <em>Diaspora Music in the Americas.</em> As an Ethnomusicology concentrator, students go on to choose from a variety of upper level classes designed to explore structure and meaning in music outside the western art music tradition through area studies, performance, and courses focusing on methodology. These include <em>Studies in Ethnomusicology, Music and Cultural Policy, Indigenous Music of the Americas, Music and Mind, Music and Modern Life, Musical Youth Cultures, American Roots Music</em>, and <em>Beyond Bossa Nova: Brazilian Music and Society</em>, to name but a few. Methodology courses introduce ideas and techniques involved in documenting and understanding music throughout the world, while topics courses explore a single subject intensively. For those who wish to study ethnomusicology in conjunction with cultural studies in jazz, there is the opportunity to combine jazz with analytical and ethnographic perspectives in classes like <em>Jazz and American Culture</em> and <em>Seminar in Jazz Studies</em>.</p>
<p>Undergraduate concentration:<br /><a href="http://brown.edu/academics/music/undergraduate/concentration-requirements">Degree requirements</a></p>
<div></div>
<h6><a name="graduatelevel"></a>Ph.D Degree</h6>
<p><em>Please note: the graduate program in Ethnomusicology will not be accepting any applications for the 2018-19 academic year.</em></p>
<p>Brown has offered the M.A. and Ph.D. in ethnomusicology since 1968.Past and current graduate students have researched such topics as flamenco guitar in Spain, folk music in the Tatra Mountains of Poland, music education in Egypt and Jordan, music and politics in a community radio station, Arab music in Indonesia, international interventions meant to reconstruct identity through music in formerly war-torn Bosnia, and the old-time string band musical culture of southwestern Virginia. A Brown doctoral degree in Music with specialization in ethnomusicology leads to a career in college and university teaching, or to a position in applied ethnomusicology outside of the academic world.</p>
<h6><a name="ethnofaculty"></a>Faculty</h6>
<p><br />C. Joshua Tucker - Assistant Professor of Music and Director of Graduate Studies<br /><a href="https://vivo.brown.edu/display/ctucker">Website</a> | <a href="mailto:Joshua_Tucker@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">Joshua Tucker</a></p>
<p>Kiri Miller - Associate Professor of Music<br /><a href="https://vivo.brown.edu/display/km8">Website</a> | <a href="mailto:Kiri_Miller@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">Kiri Miller</a></p>
<p>Marc Perlman - Associate Professor of Music<br /><a href="https://vivo.brown.edu/display/mperlman">Website</a> | <a href="mailto:Marc_Perlman@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">Marc Perlman</a></p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<hr />
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>Additional information for entrance to the Ph.D program:<br /><a href="http://www.brown.edu/academics/gradschool/apply">How to apply</a>&nbsp;(Deadline: January 7)<br /><a href="http://brown.edu/academics/music/degree-requirements-and-sample-programs">Degree requirements&nbsp;</a><br /><a href="https://wiki.brown.edu/confluence/display/musicgrad/grad+programs+FAQ">Admissions FAQ</a>&nbsp;</p>
</div>
  </div>

</div>
  
  
  
</div> </div>
			
				
	</div>

						</div><!-- end .third-column -->
							
				</div><!-- end .marginator -->
			</div><!-- end #content -->


		<section id="content-bottom">

	<div id="block-ultibanner-0" class="clear-block block block-ultibanner ">
	
		
		<div class="content">



	<!--div id="node-3022" class="ultibanner banner"-->
		<img  class="imagefield imagefield-field_ultibanner_image" width="940" height="200" alt="" src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/music/sites/brown.edu.academics.music/files/ultibanner/News-Header-940x200.jpg?1501098105" />	<!--/div-->

<!-- Layout -->

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Graduate Student David Fossum Wins Charles Seeger Prize</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								

<article class="content news_story clear-block main-article">

<div class="p details">
    <span class="date">December 13, 2012</span>
</div>






<div style="width: 300px; " class="inline-right photo-wrapper main-image">
	  <a href="/academics/music/sites/brown.edu.academics.music/files/images/news/2013/David-Fossum_0.jpg" class="thickbox"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/music/sites/brown.edu.academics.music/files/imagecache/ursa_feature_image/images/news/2013/David-Fossum_0.jpg" alt="" title="" width="300" height="340" class="imagecache imagecache-ursa_feature_image"/></a>
  		  </div>





	<div class="body">
		<p>Congratulations to David Fossum for being awarded the <strong>Charles Seeger Prize</strong>, an honor that recognizes the most distinguished student paper presented at the Society of Ethnomusicology Annual Meeting.&nbsp;</p>
<p>At the meeting, Michael Frishkopf, Associate Professor of Music at the University of Alberta, praised <em>Musical Canons in Ethnomusicology: The Case of Turkmen Instrumental Music</em>, stating:</p>
<p style="padding-left:60px">Fossum's paper, building on work by Rachel Harris, Carys Wyn Jones, Katherine Bergeron, Bruno Nettl, Harry Powers, and others, extends the concept of musical canon from the paradigmatic case of the Western art music canon to Turkmen dutar music. While situating his work in larger disciplinary conversations about musical canon, he arrives at the specificity of his own project through careful ethnographic and musicological engagement with Turkmenistan performance. Fossum illustrates how a canon has coalesced around individually developed variants of traditional instrumental pieces, especially as preserved in classic recordings that are treated as models by subsequent musicians.</p>
<p style="padding-left:60px">In his nuanced analysis of the complex interplay of modernist nationalism and indigenous musical ideals, Fossum intervenes in an understanding of canon as a static collection of exemplary works, instead characterizing the Turkmen canon as reliant on local practices of memory and performance that predate the nationalist project. He explores the senses in which this effective canonization is at once a modern and traditional phenomenon, and in doing so he provides an interpretive framework that can serve as a model for further studies of other music traditions. This paper makes an important contribution to ethnomusicology by pointing to the efficacy of canon as an analytical construct across a range of modernist nationalist contexts while insisting on the specificity and musical agency of local practices of canonization.<span>&nbsp;</span></p>
	</div>

	




</article>
							</div>

							
													</div><!-- end .second-column -->
						
													<div id="sidebar-left" class="sidebar first-column column">
								
	
	<div id="block-menu-primary-links" class="clear-block block block-menu ">

	</div>


	
	<div id="block-brown_social_media-0" class="clear-block block block-brown_social_media ">

		<img  class="imagefield imagefield-field_ultibanner_image" width="940" height="200" alt="" src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/music/sites/brown.edu.academics.music/files/ultibanner/News-Header-940x200.jpg?1501098105" />	<!--/div-->
