<!-- Layout -->

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">MEME Grad has article published</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								

<article class="content news_story clear-block main-article">

<div class="p details">
    <span class="date">November 21, 2014</span>
</div>






<div style="width: 299px; " class="inline-right photo-wrapper main-image">
	  <a href="/academics/music/sites/brown.edu.academics.music/files/images/news/2012/KristinaWolfe_4.jpg" class="thickbox"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/music/sites/brown.edu.academics.music/files/imagecache/ursa_feature_image/images/news/2012/KristinaWolfe_4.jpg" alt="" title="" width="299" height="450" class="imagecache imagecache-ursa_feature_image"/></a>
  				<div class="caption">
			<strong class="image-title">Kristina Wolfe</strong>								</div>
		  </div>





	<div class="body">
		<p>Kristina Wolfe's article—"<strong>Sonification and the Mysticism of Negation</strong>"—was recently published in <em>Organized Sound</em> by Cambridge University Press. In the article she discusses "the similarities between sonification and apophatic mysticism, or the mysticism of negation" and argues that "the practice of sonification, as a source of mystical information, is ideally suited for creative contemplation, particularly in electronic music."&nbsp;<a href="http://dx.doi.org/10.1017/S1355771814000296" rel="nofollow"> Read more...</a></p>
	</div>

	




</article>
							</div>

							
													</div><!-- end .second-column -->

		<section id="content-bottom">
			
<div id="spotlight" class="clear-block block block-views the-bar">

  <h2>Spotlight</h2>
  <div class="content"><div class="view view-thebar view-id-thebar view-display-id-block_1 view-dom-id-3">
    
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
      <ul class="jcarousel jcarousel-view--thebar--block-1 jcarousel-dom-1 jcarousel-skin-default">
      <li class="jcarousel-item-1 odd">  
  <div class="views-field-field-bar-image-fid">
                <span class="field-content"><a href="http://www.browndailyherald.com/2017/10/03/lumen-gallery-provide-new-meditative-space-granoff/"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/music/sites/brown.edu.academics.music/files/imagecache/bar_item_image/bar-items/images/granoff-650x397.jpg" alt="" title="" width="160" height="90" class="imagecache imagecache-bar_item_image imagecache-default imagecache-bar_item_image_default"/></a></span>
  </div>
  
  <div class="views-field-tid">
                <span class="field-content">In The News</span>
  </div>
  
  <div class="views-field-title">
                <span class="field-content"><a href="http://www.browndailyherald.com/2017/10/03/lumen-gallery-provide-new-meditative-space-granoff/">‘Lumen’ gallery to provide new meditative space in Granoff</a></span>
  </div>
</li>
  </ul>
    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div> </div>

	<div id="block-ultibanner-0" class="clear-block block block-ultibanner ">
	
		
		<div class="content">



	<!--div id="node-3022" class="ultibanner banner"-->
		<img  class="imagefield imagefield-field_ultibanner_image" width="940" height="200" alt="" src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/music/sites/brown.edu.academics.music/files/ultibanner/News-Header-940x200.jpg?1501098105" />	<!--/div-->

<!-- Layout -->

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">MEME grad publishes in &quot;Qui Parle&quot;</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								

<article class="content news_story clear-block main-article">

<div class="p details">
    <span class="date">November 7, 2014</span>
</div>






<div style="width: 450px; " class="inline-right photo-wrapper main-image">
	  <a href="/academics/music/sites/brown.edu.academics.music/files/images/news/2012/SethThorn_0.jpg" class="thickbox"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/music/sites/brown.edu.academics.music/files/imagecache/ursa_feature_image/images/news/2012/SethThorn_0.jpg" alt="" title="" width="450" height="450" class="imagecache imagecache-ursa_feature_image"/></a>
  		  </div>





	<div class="body">
		<p>Seth Thorn's translation of Christoph Menke's "The Aesthetic Possibility  of the Work of Art" was just published in Berkeley's prestigious  journal of the humanities, <a href="http://quiparle.berkeley.edu" rel="nofollow"><em>Qui Parle</em></a>.&nbsp; According to the journal, <em>Qui Parle</em> publishes 'provocative articles covering a range of outstanding  theoretical and critical work in the humanities and social sciences.  Founded in 1986 by an editorial board at the University of California at  Berkeley, and published by the University of Nebraska Press, the  journal aims not only to foster dialogue across the disciplines but also  to introduce hitherto under-examined analytic modes and  underrepresented critical voices.'</p>
	</div>

	




</article>
							</div>

							
													</div><!-- end .second-column -->
						
													<div id="sidebar-left" class="sidebar first-column column">
								
	
	<div id="block-menu-primary-links" class="clear-block block block-menu ">
	
		
		<div class="content"><ul class="menu"><li class="leaf first menu-home"><a href="/academics/music/news" title="Home">Home</a></li>
<li class="collapsed menu-about"><a href="/academics/music/about" title="">About</a></li>
<li class="collapsed menu-people"><a href="/academics/music/people" title="People">People</a></li>
<li class="collapsed menu-undergraduate"><a href="/academics/music/undergraduate" title="Undergraduate">Undergraduate</a></li>
<li class="collapsed menu-graduate"><a href="/academics/music/graduate" title="Graduate">Graduate</a></li>
<li class="leaf menu-courses"><a href="/academics/music/courses" title="Display Department Course Information">Courses</a></li>
<li class="collapsed menu-ensemblesandlessons"><a href="/academics/music/ensembles-and-lessons" title="Ensembles and Lessons">Ensembles and Lessons</a></li>

</ul></div>
			
				
	</div>


	
	<div id="block-brown_social_media-0" class="clear-block block block-brown_social_media ">

<!-- Layout -->

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Students enroll in open graduate program</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								

<article class="content news_story clear-block main-article">

<div class="p details">
    <span class="date">November 6, 2014</span>
</div>






<div style="width: 510px; " class="inline-right photo-wrapper main-image">
	  <a href="/academics/music/sites/brown.edu.academics.music/files/images/news/2012/BrianHouse2.jpg" class="thickbox"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/music/sites/brown.edu.academics.music/files/imagecache/ursa_feature_image/images/news/2012/BrianHouse2.jpg" alt="" title="" width="510" height="339" class="imagecache imagecache-ursa_feature_image"/></a>
  				<div class="caption">
			<strong class="image-title">Pictured: Brian House, Ph.D. MEME candidate</strong>								</div>
		  </div>





	<div class="body">
		<p>Brian House, Asha Tamarisa, Seth Thorn and Christopher Roberson-Johnson have enrolled in the Brown University Graduate School's <a href="http://www.brown.edu/academics/gradschool/opengraduateeducation">Open Graduate Program</a>. The program allows up to 14 doctoral students annually from any discipline to pursue a master’s degree in any secondary field.&nbsp; Brian and Asha are pursuing the A.M. in Modern Culture and Media in addition to working on their Ph.D. in Computer Music and Multimedia [MEME]. Seth,&nbsp; also a MEME student, is getting his Master's in German Studies, while Christopher, an Ethnomusicology Ph.D. candidate, is pursuing his master's degree in Computer Science.&nbsp;&nbsp; <a href="http://brown.edu/academics/gradschool/news/2014-03/phd-students-broaden-goals-open-graduate-education">More....</a></p>
	</div>

	




</article>
							</div>

							
													</div><!-- end .second-column -->

		<section id="content-bottom">
			
<div id="spotlight" class="clear-block block block-views the-bar">

  <h2>Spotlight</h2>
  <div class="content"><div class="view view-thebar view-id-thebar view-display-id-block_1 view-dom-id-3">
    
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
      <ul class="jcarousel jcarousel-view--thebar--block-1 jcarousel-dom-1 jcarousel-skin-default">
      <li class="jcarousel-item-1 odd">  
  <div class="views-field-field-bar-image-fid">
                <span class="field-content"><a href="http://www.browndailyherald.com/2017/10/03/lumen-gallery-provide-new-meditative-space-granoff/"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/music/sites/brown.edu.academics.music/files/imagecache/bar_item_image/bar-items/images/granoff-650x397.jpg" alt="" title="" width="160" height="90" class="imagecache imagecache-bar_item_image imagecache-default imagecache-bar_item_image_default"/></a></span>
  </div>
  
  <div class="views-field-tid">
                <span class="field-content">In The News</span>
  </div>
  
  <div class="views-field-title">
                <span class="field-content"><a href="http://www.browndailyherald.com/2017/10/03/lumen-gallery-provide-new-meditative-space-granoff/">‘Lumen’ gallery to provide new meditative space in Granoff</a></span>
  </div>
</li>
  </ul>
    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div> </div>

  
    <style type="text/css">
      .view-thebar .jcarousel-skin-default .jcarousel-clip-horizontal, .view-thebar .jcarousel-skin-default .jcarousel-container-horizontal {
        width: 180px; /* each item is 157px + 23px of padding/margin */
      }
      .view-thebar .jcarousel-skin-default .jcarousel-clip-vertical, .view-thebar .jcarousel-skin-default .jcarousel-container-vertical {
        height: 225px;
      }
      .view-thebar .jcarousel-skin-default .jcarousel-clip-vertical {
        height: 205px;
      }
  </style>
  <!--[if lt IE 10]>
    <style type="text/css">
      .view-thebar {
        margin-top: -20px;
      }
    </style>
  <![endif]-->
</div>
	</section>
	

    </div><!-- End #wrapper -->

	<div id="block-ultibanner-0" class="clear-block block block-ultibanner ">
	
		
		<div class="content">



	<!--div id="node-3022" class="ultibanner banner"-->
		<img  class="imagefield imagefield-field_ultibanner_image" width="940" height="200" alt="" src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/music/sites/brown.edu.academics.music/files/ultibanner/News-Header-940x200.jpg?1501098105" />	<!--/div-->

<!-- Layout -->

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">New Fall Courses</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								

<article class="content news_story clear-block main-article">

<div class="p details">
    <span class="date">August 26, 2015</span>
</div>









	<div class="body">
		<h3><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:203px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/music/sites/brown.edu.academics.music/files/images/-1_0.preview.jpg" alt="Keith Richards" title="Keith Richards"  class="image image-preview " width="195" height="128" /><span class="caption"><strong>Keith Richards</strong></span></span>Technology, Ecology, Rock and Roll, the Music Industry, and Social Protest</h3>
<p>The music department is offering several new courses this semester covering a variety of topics taught by new and visiting music professors, including a course at the Cogut Center for Humanities. These classes blur the boundaries between computer music, ethnomusicology and pop culture.</p>
<h6>MUSC 0033 From the Blues to Beyoncé: Rock, A Portrait of America</h6>
<p>This course seeks to view American cultural and social history of the last century through the lens of rock music. We will investigate the history of rock and popular music from its roots in the early twentieth-century to the present. We will examine the social, cultural and political contexts that gave birth to the various genres of rock music by exploring the music through the lenses of race, class, gender, advances in technology, and developments in the music business. No musical background is required.&nbsp;<em><strong> T/Th 1:00-2:20pm.</strong> Prof. Eric Nathan</em></p>
<h6>MUSC0065 Music and Social Protest</h6>
<p>This class will explore music as a vehicle for social protest, including  historical examinations of music within the U.S. labor and civil rights  movements, music and political campaigns, contemporary activist street  bands (with a field trip to the Providence HONK! festival), and other  examples from global independence and social justice movements in  Nigeria, South Africa, Brazil, Estonia, Indonesia, and others. Students  will write: two short papers on the role of music within recent protest  movements, a midterm essay, and a final research paper on a protest  topic of their choice. No previous musical background necessary; open to  all students. <em><strong>MWF 2:00-2:50pm </strong>Prof. Sheryl Kaskowitz </em></p>
<h6>MUSC1945 Wax, Tape, Wire: Music Technologies from Phonograph to Laptop</h6>
<p>This seminar-practicum explores the art, science, and politics of music  technology from a variety of theoretical and experimental perspectives.   Topics will include early mechanical instruments; World War II radio;  1960s-70s studio innovations (multitrack, analog synthesis, tape  effects); and contemporary “virtual” tech (mp3, Internet, remix apps).   We will read from ethnomusicology, music history, cultural studies, and  cognitive science.  Most class meetings will include lab where students  will create sound projects related to course topics.  We will work with  Ableton Live software, plus samplers, drum machines, and vinyl.  No  previous musical or technological training required.  Enrollment limited  to 15. <strong><em>F</em></strong><em><strong> 3:00-5:20pm </strong>Prof. Sarah Hankins </em></p>
<h6>MUSC1270 Making it in the Music Business: New Artist Model</h6>
<p>This course examines the music industry and highlights areas where music and business intersect. Students will work in groups to explore the role of artists as they form a band, create original music, work with producers, record music, and plan a tour to develop and maintain their fanbase. Students will learn the building blocks of a successful musical career including copyrights, fan engagement, social marketing, building and managing the artist’s team, forming business entities, budgeting, taxes, and intellectual property rights. We will examine the publishing, recording, and touring industries and explore methods and tools for developing a sustainable business strategy. <em><strong>W 3:00-5:20pm </strong>Prof. Valerie Lovely</em></p>
<h6><strong>HMAN1971N-S01 Music, Nature, Ecology</strong></h6>
<p>This course explores how music mediates human relations to the natural world. Via case studies drawn from Western music history and from non-Western societies, we will examine how theorists use sound to think through the difference between humans and non-humans, particularly birds and whales; how composers like Grieg, Ives, and John Luther Adams seek to shape listeners’ perceptions of natural worlds and ecological systems; how people in Papua New Guinea, Mongolia, and the Peruvian Andes use sound to communicate ecological knowledge and to coordinate environmental relationships; and how instrument making forces practitioners to contend with resource extraction and climatological concerns.&nbsp;Some music literacy highly recommended. <em><strong>Thurs. 4:00-6:20pm</strong> Prof. Joshua Tucker</em></p>
<div class="image-clear"></div>	</div>

	




</article>
							</div>

							
													</div><!-- end .second-column -->
						
													<div id="sidebar-left" class="sidebar first-column column">
								
	
	<div id="block-menu-primary-links" class="clear-block block block-menu ">

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">New Spring Courses</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								

<article class="content news_story clear-block main-article">

<div class="p details">
    <span class="date">October 30, 2015</span>
</div>






<div style="width: 300px; " class="inline-right photo-wrapper main-image">
	  <a href="/academics/music/sites/brown.edu.academics.music/files/images/news/2012/springcourses2_1.jpg" class="thickbox"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/music/sites/brown.edu.academics.music/files/imagecache/ursa_feature_image/images/news/2012/springcourses2_1.jpg" alt="" title="" width="300" height="300" class="imagecache imagecache-ursa_feature_image"/></a>
  		  </div>





	<div class="body">
		<h3><br />Exploring Global Musical Legacies, North African Music, Experimental Sound Works, and Messiean's Life and Music</h3>
<p>The music department is offering several new courses in the Spring, spanning an exciting range of diverse topics: SuperCollider programming, the music of the Mediterranean and North Africa, the intersection of politics, art, and religion, and the life and music of Olivier Messaien. See below for descriptions, times, and instructors.</p>
<p><strong>MUSC 1290 Analog/Digital Hybrids</strong><br />This intensive studio course focuses on the creation of experimental sound works utilizing hybrid analog/digital systems developed by class members. Students will investigate synthesis techniques via the SuperCollider programming language/environment and Brown’s ARP 2500 analog modular synthesizer, and leverage these tools' unique strengths towards a personal production platform that is more than the sum of its parts. Weekly meetings include discussion of historical works, hands-on demonstrations, in-class projects, and critical engagement with new works by class members, culminating in a final project incorporating knowledge gained throughout the semester. Limited enrollment. Attendance at first class mandatory. Prerequisite: MUSC1210 or written permission. <em>Tues. 4:00-6:20 p.m. / LAB on Mon. 3:00-5:20 p.m. Mr. Cetilia</em></p>
<p><strong>MUSC 1500B Major Masters and Repertoires of Music: Olivier Messiaen</strong><br />This seminar explores Messiaen’s life, theoretical writings, and above all his music. Listening and analysis will focus on Messiaen’s idiosyncratic harmonic and rhythmic language as well as performance practice issues. We will investigate Messiaen’s use of color, plainsong, “modes of limited transposition,” “personages rhythmic,” birdsong, serialism, Greek modes, and Indian ragas via representative works. We will also examine Messiaen’s formation and his legacy as teacher/composer/performer. Final project is either student performance/analysis or a theoretical/historical paper. Prerequisite MUSC 0560. Class size limited to 20. <em>Wed. 3:00-5:20 p.m. Prof. Steinbach</em><em></em></p>
<p><strong>MUSC1675 Music, Religion, Politics</strong><br />This is a course about the cultural origins and the national and global legacies of central European musical traditions and their role in the building, survival, and transformations of the city of Berlin. How do we understand the cultural importance of musical works, performance, and experience at the intersection of art, politics, and religion (including the process of and debates over secularization)?&nbsp; How has music served to build both inner life and community, including the “imagined community” of the nation?&nbsp; How do we understand the legacy of European and national musics for the age of globalization?&nbsp; Written permission required. Interested students must submit a brief essay to the instructor, indicating why they wish to be in the class and how it fits into their curriculum. <em>Thurs. 4:00-6:20 p.m. Prof. Michael Steinberg</em></p>
<p><strong>MUSC 1905E Music in the Middle East and North Africa</strong><br />This course provides an introduction to the music of the eastern Mediterranean, north Africa, Turkey, and Iran. Throughout this tour we will view music culture through a variety of thematic lenses. We will see how music is implicated in identitarian discourses; how musical forms transcend political boundaries, ethnic lines, and religious divides; how religion constrains and stimulates musical expression; and how music intersects with gender and sexuality. We will explore elite, folk, and popular genres. Though we will also discuss musical structures and terminology, no musical training is necessary for this course. <em>MWF 10:00-10:50 a.m. Mr. Fossum</em></p>
	</div>

	




</article>
							</div>

							
													</div><!-- end .second-column -->

          <li class="views-row views-row-1 views-row-odd views-row-first views-row-last">  
  <div class="views-field-title">
                <span class="field-content"><a href="/academics/music/events/lessons-carols">Lessons &amp; Carols</a></span>
  </div>
</li>
      </ul>
</div>    </div>

  <a href="/academics/music/events">
    View Full Calendar  </a>
</div>
  
  
  
</div> </div>
			
				
	</div>

						</div><!-- end .third-column -->
							
				</div><!-- end .marginator -->
			</div><!-- end #content -->


		<section id="content-bottom">

		<div class="content">



	<!--div id="node-3022" class="ultibanner banner"-->
		<img  class="imagefield imagefield-field_ultibanner_image" width="940" height="200" alt="" src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/music/sites/brown.edu.academics.music/files/ultibanner/News-Header-940x200.jpg?1501098105" />	<!--/div-->

<!-- Layout -->

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Ethnomusicology Graduate Student David Fossum wins 2016 Rob Schultz Junior Scholar Award</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								

<article class="content news_story clear-block main-article">

<div class="p details">
    <span class="date">September 30, 2016</span>
</div>









	<div class="body">
		<p>From Aaron Pettigrew, Assistant Editor, Analytical Approaches to World Music...</p>
<blockquote><p>The editors of the <a href="http://aawmjournal.com/" rel="nofollow">Analytical Approaches to World Music (AAWM) </a>journal are pleased to announce that the winner of the 2016 Rob Schultz Junior Scholar Award is David Fossum for his paper "Principles of Transmission and Collective Composition in Turkmen Dutar Performance". Congratulations David, and thank you to everyone who submitted.</p>
<p>The <a href="https://www.generosity.com/memorial-fundraising/rob-schultz-junior-scholar-award" rel="nofollow">Rob Schultz Junior Scholar Award</a> is open to presenters at the biennial AAWM conference who are graduate students or young scholars within five years of graduation. It was established by the editors and organizers of the AAWM journal and conference series, working in close association with Rob’s family, to honor our dear friend and colleague who passed away unexpectedly in May 2016. The winning article is published in the AAWM journal, and the author also receives a modest cash award.</p>
</blockquote>
	</div>

	




</article>
							</div>

							
													</div><!-- end .second-column -->

				<div id="content">

					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">New Music Courses for Fall 2016</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								

<article class="content news_story clear-block main-article">

<div class="p details">
    <span class="date">September 6, 2016</span>
</div>









	<div class="body">
		<p>The music department has listed new courses for the Fall 2016 semester! Find information about them <a href="https://www.brown.edu/academics/music/news/2016-09/new-music-courses-fall-2016">here</a>...</p>

<h3>Music in History, from Hildegard to Hamilton - MUSC 0010</h3>
<p>A study of a thousand years of music of Europe and America through CDs, DVDs, and YouTube. We'll explore how individuals, institutions, and societies create music, use it, experience it, pay for it, and control it. We'll discuss music and time, music and politics, music and identity. Still, the heart of the course is listening to great music, and learning how it works.CRN 17272</p>
<p>M/W/F 1pm in Orwig Music Hall 315-1:50pm</p>
<h3><br />Music, Nation, and Identity in the Middle East - MUSC 0045</h3>
<p>The Middle East, generally understood to include Iran, Turkey, the Arabian Peninsula, Egypt, and the Levant, is home to a diversity of musical traditions that mirrors the region’s diversity of religions, languages, and other cultural expressions. In this course, we will take an in­-depth look at several of these traditions; by listening closely to music and to the people who engage in it, students will be able to understand the always-­shifting role of music in several Middle Eastern societies. There are no prerequisites, but a background in music or a willingness to listen deeply will be very helpful. DPLL. CRN 17447</p>
<p>T/Th 1pm-2:20pm in Orwig Music Hall 109</p>
<h3><br />World Music Ensemble - MUSC 0642</h3>
<p>This ensemble focuses on global percussive and song traditions, especially those of the African diaspora (based on instructor's vast musical experiences). Here western instrumentalists fuse with traditional musicians from every culture: bongo, gyil, ukulele, tabla, etc. Students will grow and develop their musical skills by learning new techniques on their own instrument, exploring a range of repertoire representing genres such as highlife, reggae, salsa, afrobeat, Afro-jazz, and global fusions. There will be unique opportunities to work on improvisation taking influence from Steve Reich, Tito Puente, Randy Weston, Hugh Masekela, Paul Simon, Miriam Makeba, Ghanaba, and Milton Nasimiento. DPLL Half credit. For more information, contact <a href="mailto:Martin_Obeng@brown.edu">Martin_Obeng@brown.edu</a>. Auditions will be held on Monday 9/12 from 7-9pm in Orwig 301. CRN 17448</p>
<p>M 7pm-9pm in Orwig Music Hall 301</p>
<h3><br />Making it in the Music Business: The New Artist Model - MUSC 1270</h3>
<p>The historic music industry provides a cautionary case study for artists and entrepreneurs. For musicians and artists of any genre, an understanding of the traditional music industry - from copyright to marketing to ethics - provides baseline “rules” that allow for optimal decision making with respect to artistic careers. For entrepreneurs, the models utilized from the music industry provide both a cautionary tale and line of sight; as goes the music industry, so goes all other industries...eventually. Students will learn the fundamental principles of the historic music industry, and will review both historic and current music industry practices in order to develop strategies and tactics applicable to other industries and entrepreneurial activities. CRN 15647</p>
<p>F 11am-1:30pm in Orwig Music Hall 112</p>
	</div>

	




</article>
							</div>

							
													</div><!-- end .second-column -->

						</div><!-- end .third-column -->
							
				</div><!-- end .marginator -->
			</div><!-- end #content -->


		<section id="content-bottom">

	<!--div id="node-3022" class="ultibanner banner"-->
		<img  class="imagefield imagefield-field_ultibanner_image" width="940" height="200" alt="" src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/music/sites/brown.edu.academics.music/files/ultibanner/News-Header-940x200.jpg?1501098105" />	<!--/div-->

<!-- Layout -->

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Kristina Warren to Join MEME Program as Visiting Assistant Professor</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								

<article class="content news_story clear-block main-article">

<div class="p details">
    <span class="date">June 5, 2017</span>
</div>






<div style="width: 275px; " class="inline-right photo-wrapper main-image">
	  <a href="/academics/music/sites/brown.edu.academics.music/files/images/news/2016/kristina-warren-275.jpg" class="thickbox"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/music/sites/brown.edu.academics.music/files/imagecache/ursa_feature_image/images/news/2016/kristina-warren-275.jpg" alt="" title="" width="275" height="277" class="imagecache imagecache-ursa_feature_image"/></a>
  		  </div>





	<div class="body">
		<p>The Department of Music is proud to welcome Kristina Warren to Brown. Kristina will be a Visiting Assistant Professor in the MEME program for the next three years to help enrich both the graduate and undergraduate curriculum. Kristina Warren is a Visiting Assistant Professor in the MEME Program,  Department of Music. Her work explores intersections of performance and  technology. Recently, she presented the Abacus, an augmented microphone  instrument she designed and built, at the Guthman Musical Instrument  Competition. Warren holds a PhD in Composition &amp; Computer  Technologies (University of Virginia) and a BA in Music Composition  (Duke University). <a href="http://kmwarren.org/about.html" rel="nofollow">Learn more about Kristina on her website: http://kmwarren.org/about.html.</a></p>
	</div>

	




</article>
							</div>

							
													</div><!-- end .second-column -->
						
													<div id="sidebar-left" class="sidebar first-column column">
								
	
	<div id="block-menu-primary-links" class="clear-block block block-menu ">
	
		
		<div class="content"><ul class="menu"><li class="leaf first menu-home"><a href="/academics/music/news" title="Home">Home</a></li>

				<div id="content">

					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Undergraduate</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
<article id="node-12" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <h2>Undergraduate Opportunities in Music</h2>
<p><span>The curriculum of the Department of Music offers liberal-arts students a breadth of opportunities to develop knowledge and skills as listeners, scholars, performers, and creative artists. Courses in history, theory, ethnomusicology, and technology extend critical, analytical, and scientific modes of inquiry taught elsewhere in the University.&nbsp; Musicianship skills and elements of craft are honed through courses in theory and analysis, counterpoint, orchestration, score reading and conducting, technology, and applied-music instruction.&nbsp; An array of performance activities together with our offerings in composition and production enable students to explore modes of creative expression.</span></p>
<h3>Concentration Program &amp; Courses</h3>
<p>Concentrators in music elect to pursue one of three tracks:&nbsp;</p>
<ul>
<li><strong>Computer Music (MEME) </strong>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://www.brown.edu/academics/music/computer-music-multimedia-meme">Program information</a></li>
<li><a href="http://brown.edu/academics/music/undergraduate/concentration-requirements">Concentration requirements</a></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li><strong>Ethnomusicology </strong>
<ul>
<li><a href="http://brown.edu/academics/music/graduate/ethnomusicology">Program information</a></li>
<li><a href="http://brown.edu/academics/music/undergraduate/concentration-requirements">Concentration requirements</a></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li><strong>History, Theory, and Composition </strong>
<ul>
<li><a href="/academics/music/music-history-theory-and-composition" title="Music History, Theory and Composition" rel="nofollow">Program information</a></li>
<li><a href="http://brown.edu/academics/music/undergraduate/concentration-requirements">Concentration requirements</a></li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
<p>All three tracks include the foundation courses MUSC0550 and MUSC0560, that constitute a year-long intensive study of principles of voice leading and tonal harmony with a required musicianship lab.&nbsp; Music Concentrators are encouraged to continue to develop musicianship skills through advanced musicianship and performance courses while taking the mastery courses and electives in their chosen track.</p>
  </div>

	
  <div class="clear-block">
    <div class="meta">

			
	    
		</div><!-- end .meta -->
	</div>

</article>

		<section id="content-bottom">
			
<div id="spotlight" class="clear-block block block-views the-bar">

  <h2>Spotlight</h2>
  <div class="content"><div class="view view-thebar view-id-thebar view-display-id-block_1 view-dom-id-3">
    
  
  
      <div class="view-content">

<!-- Layout -->

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Concentration Requirements</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
<article id="node-271" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <h2><span>Music Concentration Requirements</span></h2>
<p><span>• </span><a href="#memerequirements" rel="nofollow"><span>Computer Music &amp; Multimedia&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </span></a><span>&nbsp;</span><span>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p><span>• <a href="#ethnorequirements" rel="nofollow">Ethnomusicology</a>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span> </span><span>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p><span>• </span><a href="#htcrequirements" rel="nofollow"><span>History/Theory/Composition</span></a></p>
<p><span><br /></span></p>
<h3><span><span><a name="memerequirements"></a><a href="http://brown.edu/academics/music/graduate/computer-music-multimedia-meme/about-meme">Computer Music &amp; Multimedia</a></span></span></h3>
<h6><span>Music Theory (2)</span></h6>
<p><span>MUSC 0550-0560 are prerequisite for a number of upper-level  music courses. 0550 is offered every fall; 0560 is offered every spring.</span></p>
<ul>
<li> <span>MUSC 0550: Theory of Tonal Music I</span> </li>
<li> <span>MUSC 0560: Theory of Tonal Music II</span> </li>
</ul>
<h6><span>Computer Music Foundation (3)</span></h6>
<ul>
<li> <span>MUSC 0200: Computers and Music</span> </li>
<li> <span>MUSC 1200: Seminar in Electronic Music – The Recording Studio as Compositional Tool</span> </li>
<li> <span>MUSC 1210: Seminar in Electronic Music – Real-Time Systems</span> </li>
</ul>
<h6><span>Musicology/Ethnomusicology Elective (1)</span></h6>
<p><span>One scholarly course numbered above MUSC 0900.</span></p>
<h6><span>Other Electives (4)</span></h6>
<p><span>Students must take four elective courses selected in any combination from the following groups:</span></p>
<ul>
<li> <span>Computer Music and Multimedia courses, MUSC 1220-1290 or MUSC 2200-2290</span> </li>
<li> <span>Theory and composition courses, MUSC 1020-1190</span> </li>
<li> <span>No more than one lower-level Computer Music and Multimedia course, MUSC 0210-0230</span> </li>
<li> <span>No more than one art production course (eg VISA or MCM). (See  the Concentration Advisor for current approved courses in this area.)</span></li>
</ul>
<p><span> </span></p>
<h3><span><span><a name="ethnorequirements"></a><a href="http://brown.edu/academics/music/graduate/ethnomusicology">Ethnomusicology Track</a></span></span></h3>
<h6><span>Music Theory (2)</span></h6>
<p><span>MUSC 0550-0560 are prerequisite for a number of upper-level music courses. 0550 is offered every fall; 0560 is offered every spring.</span></p>
<ul>
<li> <span>MUSC 0550: Theory of Tonal Music I</span> </li>
<li> <span>MUSC 0560: Theory of Tonal Music II</span> </li>
</ul>
<h6><span>Other Foundational Courses (2)</span></h6>
<p><span>The two (2) courses below are required. 1900 is usually offered annually and should be taken before the senior year.</span></p>
<ul>
<li> <span>ANTH 0100: Cultural Anthropology – Understanding Human Societies</span> </li>
<li> <span>MUSC 1900: Introduction to Ethnomusicology</span> </li>
</ul>
<h6><span>History (2)</span></h6>
<p><span>Any two (2) of the three courses below are required; the third is optional.</span></p>
<ul>
<li> <span>MUSC 0910: Medieval and Renaissance Music</span> </li>
<li> <span>MUSC 0920: Baroque and Classical Music</span> </li>
<li> <span>MUSC 0930: Romantic and Modern Music</span> </li>
</ul>
<h6><span>Electives in Ethnomusicology (4)</span></h6>
<p><span>Four additional courses in ethnomusicology numbered 1000 or higher are required. For a list of qualifying courses see the Concentration Advisor.</span></p>
<h3><span><a name="htcrequirements"></a><a href="/academics/music/music-history-theory-and-composition" title="Music History, Theory and Composition" rel="nofollow">History/Theory/Composition Track</a></span></h3>
<h6><span>Music Theory (2)</span></h6>
<p><span>MUSC 0550-0560 are prerequisite for a number of upper-level  music courses. 0550 is offered every fall; 0560 is offered every spring.</span></p>
<ul>
<li> <span>MUSC 0550: Theory of Tonal Music I</span> </li>
<li> <span>MUSC 0560: Theory of Tonal Music II</span> </li>
</ul>
<h6><span>History (2)</span></h6>
<p><span>Any two (2) of the three courses below are required; the third is optional.</span></p>
<ul>
<li> <span>MUSC 0910: Medieval and Renaissance Music</span> </li>
<li> <span>MUSC 0920: Baroque and Classical Music</span> </li>
<li> <span>MUSC 0930: Romantic and Modern Music</span> </li>
</ul>
<h6><span>Theory and Analysis (2)</span></h6>
<p>Any two (2) courses in theory and analysis (MUSC 1020–1090)&nbsp;are required, in no particular order. At the beginning of each&nbsp;academic year a list of offered courses fulfilling this requirement&nbsp;will be provided. Examples include Modal Counterpoint, Tonal&nbsp;Counterpoint, Messiaen, Compositional Techniques in 19th&nbsp;Century Music [formerly Advanced Music Theory I],&nbsp;Compositional Techniques in 20 th Century Music [formerly&nbsp;Advanced Music Theory II], Performance and Analysis, and&nbsp;Seminar in Advanced Orchestration and Analysis.</p>
<ul>
</ul>
<h6><span>Advanced Musicianship (1)</span></h6>
<p><span>MUSC 1010-1011 are required; each is worth ½ credit.  (Prerequisite: 0560) 1010 is offered every fall; 1011 is offered every  spring.</span></p>
<ul>
<li> <span>MUSC 1010: Advanced Musicianship I</span> </li>
<li> <span>MUSC 1011: Advanced Musicianship II</span> </li>
</ul>
<h6><span>Ethnomusicology (1)</span></h6>
<p><span>MUSC 1900 is required. 1900 is usually offered annually and should be taken before the senior year.</span></p>
<ul>
<li> <span>MUSC 1900: Introduction to Ethnomusicology</span> </li>
</ul>
<h6><span>Electives (3)</span></h6>
<p><span>Three (3) upper-level courses are required (i.e. no course  below MUSC 0570); 1600-level seminars are preferred. Up to two (2) full  Applied Music or ensemble credits (i.e. four semesters) may be applied  to the concentration requirements.</span></p>
<p><span> </span></p>
<p><span> </span></p>
<h3><span>Undergraduate Concentration Advisors</span></h3>
<p><span>Prof. Wang Lu &amp; Prof. Eric Nathan<br /><a href="mailto:music-concentration-advisors@brown.edu">music-concentration-advisors@brown.edu</a><br />Orwig Music Building</span></p>
  </div>

	
  <div class="clear-block">
    <div class="meta">

			
	    
		</div><!-- end .meta -->
	</div>

</article>
							</div>

							
													</div><!-- end .second-column -->

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Departmental Honors</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
<article id="node-269" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <h2>Honors in Music 2017-18</h2>
<p>Faculty Rules stipulate “Brown University shall, at graduation, grant honors to students whose work in a field of concentration has demonstrated superior quality and culminated in an honors thesis of distinction.”</p>
<p>In order to apply for Honors in Music, a student must fulfill the following criteria:</p>
<ol>
<li>The student must have acquired a 3.5 cumulative grade point average overall.</li>
<li>The student must also have acquired a 3.5 cumulative grade point average in courses<strong> </strong>that count toward the concentration. (“S with distinction” equates with “A”. &nbsp;Grades of “S” are not computed in the grade point average.)</li>
</ol>
<ol> </ol>
<h3>Departmental Procedures:</h3>
<p>The Department designates three kinds of projects leading to honors in music:</p>
<ol> </ol>
<p style="padding-left:30px">(a) Research project in history, theory, or ethnomusicology.<br />(b) Performance project accompanied by pertinent research of lesser scope than (a). (Scholarly program notes required)<br /> (c) Composition/Computer Music project. (score required if applicable; recording and/or video documentation desired, short project description)</p>
<p><em><em>NOTE: the term HONORS COMMITTEE refers to a student’s honors thesis advisor and readers. </em></em></p>
<p>A student wishing to propose a project should proceed as follows:</p>
<ol>
<li>An honors candidate must secure a faculty advisor and a second reader to serve as an <strong>honors committee </strong>for his or her project by the end of the year before graduation—typically, the end of the sixth semester.&nbsp; At the beginning of the penultimate semester the student will submit a proposal describing the project to the <strong>honors committee </strong>for approval. The proposal must receive committee approval and be given to Mary Rego<strong>&nbsp;</strong>for distribution to the full faculty by the first day of the first full week of classes of the semester. The department faculty will vote on the proposals at the next regularly scheduled meeting. Decisions will be based on the student’s overall performance in music courses and on the quality of the proposal. The advisor will notify the student of the faculty’s decision.</li>
<li> It is expected that honors projects will normally take two semesters to complete. Students pursuing honors may choose to register for MUSC1970 in the Fall and/or in the Spring. In any case, they will establish a series of regular meetings with their advisor. By finals week of the penultimate semester, honors candidates must demonstrate substantial progress by submitting to the <strong>honors committee </strong>a partial draft of a paper or composition or, for performance projects, by playing a significant portion of the programmed repertoire. Failure to make sufficient progress may result in the termination of the honors project.</li>
<li> Last semester deadlines: Honors candidates must submit a complete draft to their <strong>honors committee </strong>by the first day of classes following the eighth week of the last semester. The committee will comment on the project and suggest revisions. Revisions must be completed, and the final project submitted to the <strong>honors committee </strong>by the first day of classes two weeks later. In the case of performance projects, this means that both the public performance and the scholarly component must have been completed by this date. In the case of research projects, all figures, notes, bibliography, and other critical apparatus must have been completed. Failure to make the deadline may result in the forfeiting of honors by the candidate, though the student may complete the project as a capstone project.</li>
<li> The <strong>honors committee </strong>will confer to determine their views on their projects. If the second reader is outside Music, the advisor may solicit a written recommendation about the merits of the project.</li>
<li> The <strong>advisor</strong> will deliver a copy of the completed thesis to the Mary Rego&nbsp;by the middle of the eleventh week of the last semester so that it may be made available for review by the full faculty. (Online, or hard copy on reserve in the Music Library.)</li>
<li>During the twelfth week of the last semester, the <strong>advisor </strong>will report on the project at a meeting of the Department faculty for a vote.&nbsp; The <strong>advisor </strong>will notify the student of the faculty’s decision.</li>
<li>Honors recipients will present their projects at a Department of Music Convocation held once annually at noon on the first day of final examination period in Semester II.</li>
</ol>
<h3>Deadlines for Academic Year 2017-18</h3>

<h3>Deadlines for Academic Year 2016-17</h3>
<ul>
</ul>
<table class="t1">
<tbody>

</td>
<td class="td3" valign="top">
<p class="p1"><span class="s1">Projects that started in Semester II of 2016-17<br /></span></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td class="td4" valign="top">
<p class="p1"><span class="s1">Submit honors proposal to honors committee</span></p>
<p class="p1"><span class="s1">(beginning of the penultimate semester)</span></p>
</td>
<td class="td6" valign="top">
<p class="p1"><span class="s1">January 25, 2017</span></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td class="td1" valign="top">
<p class="p1"><span class="s1">Submit proposal to Mary Rego</span></p>
<p class="p1"><span class="s1">(first day of the first full week of classes)</span></p>
</td>
<td class="td3" valign="top">
<p class="p1"><span class="s1">January 30, 2017</span></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td class="td4" valign="top">
<p class="p1"><span class="s1">Faculty Meeting to approve proposals</span></p>
<p class="p1"><span class="s1">(possibly one week later)</span></p>
</td>
<td class="td6" valign="top">
<p class="p1"><span class="s1">February 14, 2017</span></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td class="td1" valign="top">
<p class="p1"><span class="s1">Partial draft due to honors committee</span></p>
<p class="p1"><span class="s1">(finals week of the penultimate semester)</span></p>
</td>
<td class="td3" valign="top">
<p class="p1"><span class="s1">May 10, 2017</span></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td class="td4" valign="top">
<p class="p1"><span class="s1">Completed draft due to honors committee</span></p>
<p class="p1"><span class="s1">(first day of classes following the eighth week)</span></p>
</td>
<td class="td6" valign="top">
<p class="p1"><span class="s1">November 6, 2017</span></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td class="td1" valign="top">
<p class="p1"><span class="s1">Final revisions due to honors committee</span></p>
<p class="p1"><span class="s1">(first day of classes two weeks later)</span></p>
</td>
<td class="td3" valign="top">
<p class="p1"><span class="s1">November 20, 2017</span></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td class="td4" valign="top">
<p class="p1"><span class="s1">Thesis delivered to Mary Rego</span></p>
<p class="p1"><span class="s1">(middle of the eleventh week)</span></p>
</td>
<td class="td6" valign="top">
<p class="p1"><span class="s1">November 22, 2017</span></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td class="td1" valign="top">
<p class="p1"><span class="s1">Faculty meeting to vote</span></p>
<p class="p1"><span class="s1">(during the twelfth week)</span></p>
</td>
<td class="td3" valign="top">
<p class="p1"><span class="s1">November 28, 2017</span></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td class="td4" valign="top">
<p class="p1"><span class="s1">Honors Presentations and Awards Ceremony</span></p>
<p class="p1"><span class="s1">(occurs once annually)</span></p>
</td>
<td class="td5" valign="top">
<p class="p1"><span class="s1">May 10, 2017</span></p>
</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
  </div>

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Music Theory Placement</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
<article id="node-270" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <h2>MUSC 0550/0560 (Theory of Tonal Music)</h2>
<p>Students  interested in taking MUSC0550 (or in placing out of MUSC0550) MUST take a  placement test at the first class meeting. Both sections of the class  will meet at that time in the same room. This will be your only  opportunity to take the test. Those who miss the test will be unable to  take MUSC0550 that year.&nbsp;</p>
<h3>Music Theory FAQs</h3>
<h4>Why should I take MUSC0550/0560?</h4>
<p>MUSC0550 and  MUSC0560 are required for all three music concentration tracks. These  courses provide a thorough grounding in principles of voice leading and  harmony that are the basis of Western music from the Renaissance through  the nineteenth century, as well as training in aural and musicianship  skills including sight singing and keyboard harmony.</p>
<h4>What if I don't want to be a concentrator but just want to take a few music courses?</h4>
<p>Many  skilled musicians choose to take MUSC0550-560 regardless of whether  they plan to concentrate. These courses are a prerequisite for a number  of upper-level music courses.</p>
<h4>What if I can't get into MUSC0550, is there a theory alternative for me?</h4>
<p>Students  who don't yet have the skills for MUSC0550 can register for MUSC0400  (Introduction to Music Theory), which is offered every year. Another  excellent way to prepare for MUSC0550 is to take private instrumental  lessons, preferably keyboard lessons, that include a strong component in  the rudiments of music.</p>
<h4>What if I took a lot of theory in high school?</h4>
<p>The  Department of Music does not award course credit for Advanced Placement  (A.P.) courses; however, students with considerable background in  theory occasionally place out of MUSC0550 and/or MUSC0560. Students  interested in placing out of MUSC0550 or MUSC0560 should take the  placement test for MUSC0550 and then consult individually with the  director of the course.</p>
<h4>When is the placement test offered?</h4>
<p>The placement  test for MUSC0550 is always offered at the first class meeting.</p>
<h4>If I want to get course credit for private lessons, will I still need to take theory?</h4>
<p>Students  taking private lessons through the Applied Music Program (AMP) are  required to take one semester of college-level theory.</p>
<h4>If I have a strong theory background, can I place out of the AMP theory requirement?</h4>
<p>Students  with extensive background in music theory can place out of the AMP  theory requirement by passing the Department's AMP theory placement  exam, which is administered at the beginning of each fall semester.  Students who pass this exam may substitute any full-credit music course  (or two half-credit music courses) for the required music theory course.</p>
<h4>When and where is the AMP theory placement exam administered?</h4>
<p>The  theory exam is administered on the first day of classes.</p>
<h4>Do I just show up or do I have to let someone know I want to take the AMP theory placement exam?</h4>
<p>You can show up to the scheduled test, which will be announced on the auditions schedule.</p>
<h4>What if I'm not available at the time the AMP theory placement exam is given?</h4>
<p>Students who wish to take the exam but are unable to take it at the specified time should be in touch with <a href="mailto:arlene_cole@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">Arlene Cole</a> as soon as possible.</p>
  </div>

	
  <div class="clear-block">
